author: RJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2018
review_content: This modem was great and behaved exactly as advertised, but only for two months. I started to notice spotty internet last week and blamed it on Comcast and then my internet went completely out 3 days ago. All the modem lights were on, my router was working fine, but I couldn't get internet. The Comcast technician came over for an hour today until we finally realized the modem wasn't responding correctly so I replaced this with my old modem and got my internet back.So there you go bought Jun. 13, officially dead Aug. 14. Outside of the return period and now I'm stuck with a paperweight. The technician also warned me against Netgear modems too, he said they tend to fail earlier. I do NOT recommend getting this you can get cheaper more reliable modems (Arris). Thanks Netgear for disappointing me, you've lost a fan.
title: Stopped working after 2 months

author: Donna B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2018
review_content: I have had this modem for a little over 6 months and it has not been reliable. It was fine for the first three months but then it started loosing connection. I would restart the modem and it would work okay for awhile and start acting up again. All morning it has been working for about 15 mins and then it’s down. I’m glad that I forgot to turn in the modem I had been renting from my ISP. I hooked it up and have not had any trouble. I am so disappointed in this modem. I am normally a Netgear fan but this has been nothing but trouble. I do more streaming than anything and I have work I have to do on my iPad a lot and this is unacceptable.
title: Trouble

author: YEMSG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2018
review_content: We have Comcast, this modem is supported by Comcast and it’s super easy to set up. It took less than ten minutes. If you have Comcast there are specific instructions to set it up. Very easy.The modem works so far. Our internet speeds are where they are supposed to be.Stop renting your modem and buy it!As for technical stuff I have no idea what any of it is without googling something.I paired it with a LINKSYS EA7300 wireless router and am now enjoying way better connectivity.
title: Average Guy, not a techie

author: Roman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2019
review_content: I was weary of some negative reviews at first, but after reading online reviews from reputable sources, and trying it for myself, this modem is simply amazing!First off, setup was super easy. In a nutshell:1.) Power it up.2.) Connect Ethernet cable from modem to laptop and go to xfinity.com/activate3.) All you need to do is login like you're about to pay a bill and that's it - no account numbers or anything!4.) CALL XFINITY TO ACTIVATE YOUR EQUIPMENT!!! Do not skip this step!5.) Tell them the Serial Number and MAC Address (DOCSIS 3.1, not the DOCSIS 3.0 - look closely on the unit, not on the box, there are (2) MAC addresses, provide the 3.1 number).6.) Connect modem to router via Ethernet (Cat 6 minimum), connect phone line,  and you're gucci.Literally all those steps took me less than 15 minutes, including the call to XFinity.I had been wanting to switch to my own modem and start saving $11 per month (plus taxes) for a while, and finally decided to go for it. I hated paying the rental and then I also found out another little detail, you know that free XFinity hotspot thing they keep talking about, ever wonder where that comes from, that's right, your rental modem/router. That sucker is turned on by default and XFinity is using your electricity to power up a public XFinity hotspot. Totally lame, I killed it ASAP in the XFinity My Account application as soon as I realized that. Next thing I did with the rental was turn off the WiFi by switching the unit into Bridge mode. Just some advice for people still renting. I highly recommend switching to bridge and using your own router, it's way better than theirs. Better yet, buy your own modem and route. Ok, rant over, back to review.It is easily two times, if not three times smaller than the rental modem/router unit. Kinda goes as a given since it's one device replacing two. And to that point, it is better to have two discrete devices than two devices in one package for reliability and ease of diagnosis. The device is also very discrete looking and sufficiently aesthetic, at least to me, to be in plain sight. Overall, the build quality, construction, and overall perception does seem to line up with the price tag. I feel like I'm getting my money's worth for the time being. Reliability will ultimately solidify or uproot that.It boots up way quicker than the rental (~1-2 min) and performs better. The latency on my speed tests went down from 12-15 to about 7-9ms aand I'm getting just slightly better downloads but not by much. However, this is one of two of the only XFinity approved DOCSIS 3.1 modems - think up to 10Gbps connection. Now I'm on blast - 250mbps (getting all 250 and then some) but am thinking of going to 1Gbps. And while we're dreaming,  this modem will do 2Gbps with link aggregation, but the software update is still in the works. Basically two Ethernet cables from your modem going to your router, each 1Gbps but acting like a "single" cable to provide 2Gbps of total throughput. Way out of the league of most people, but XFinity does have a 2Gbps option over coax so I figured I'd throw it out there.I have only had it for a few days, but was so thrilled with the easy set-up and exceptional performance, I decided to leave a review. I will update ofcourse over the years with reliability and how it holds up, but so far, very promising.
title: Best 3.1 DOCSIS Modem for XFinity

author: ImHighAsAKite
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
review_content: This thing broke down less than 2 months. Contacted customer support from Netgear, I was told I would have to send my unit back before they send out a replacement. Don't buy this garbage. If your modem breaks down you're going to have to wait at least 3 or 4 weeks before you get another one back. That's a long time now that everything's connected to the internet. I should have read the bad reviews before I bought it.
title: Broke down in less than 2 months

author: Mario Jr.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018
review_content: This is the best purchase for modem, I currently had (ARRIS SURFboard SB6121 4x4 DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem pair with router NightHawk X10) and start failing me with speed dropping completely to 0MB/s at times. Tested by connecting it directly modem to desktop and was getting same speed dropping. I have Blast (250MB/s DL & 10MB UL/s) speed from Xfinity Comcast, with the old modem didn't see speed higher than 135MB/s DL. That wasn't bad until it started to failed, then I realized that it has not been my IP fault I wasn't getting the full 250MB/s, it was me with an older modem with top DL of 175MB/s capable. I started to research to see what modem to buy and since I already have the router Netgear NightHawk X10 and no problem, I look into netgear modem and read the awesome review this one has, so I decided to go for it. Installed it and the first speed test I did it blew my mind with speed of almost 300MB/s DL!!!!  Now it is a steady 250MB/s DL speed (+/- 30MB/s) I turn every device and streamed HD videos some ULTRA HD and not one ever buffered.  100% Recommend this product worth every penny ($179.99 + tax)! Bought Friday 27th 2018.
title: Instant speed upgrade!!

author: MJD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2019
review_content: My family has endured angry outbursts, grumpy attitude, and me cursing at this thing trying to get it to work. In addition they were deprived of one of the most valuable human needs: WiFi. Read on if you want to read a story of hope, heartache, and restoration. tl;dr this Netgear modem sucks.I bought this one because my Xfinity Double Play (150 Mbps internet + Cable) package expired and was charging me $60 more in fees. Calling Xfinity, they were able to lower my bill. Double Play and Triple Play happened to be the same price with current promotions. Thinking I was getting a good deal I signed up for the Triple Play not knowing that I would need a new modem (shame on me), as I was on an older DOCSIS 3.0 modem w/o voice support, and Xfinity was unable to finalize my order until I installed a modem that could handle voice.I was NOT going to pay the $13/month to rent their modem, so I decided to jump online and grab this one. I was ecstatic that it was arriving the next day! That was the only good thing about this whole story. I set it up and had the WORST time trying to get it to activate. The connection from the Ethernet port to the laptop was laughably slow. I had to refresh 10 times and wait for the next page to load through the activation process, hoping it wouldn't timeout and lose my progress. It finally went through and was able to activate the new modem. This should have been a huge red flag, but I tend to slog through problems and apparently am a glutton for punishment. Read on.Fool me once: The issue is that the internet was a tease. It would come online for a few minutes and then disconnect for 5+ minutes. You never really knew when it would come back online or for how long. Then it would come back online, then go off again. I called Comcast but they were only able to send a reset signal to the modem once in every 2 calls. It was an awful experience, especially for someone who has to work from home a couple days a week.Fool me twice: I finally identified that the major change that caused the issue was the modem, so I decided to replace the original one for a new one. Amazon is awesome and sent one within 2 days. I was eager to get the one "fluke" modem out of here and install the new one. After another call with Comcast, they were able to activate the new one. It seemed to be working great with amazing speeds... until it didn't. Internet started going wonky and once again I was being subjected to the schizophrenic connection.After wasting valuable time trying to get this thing to work, I finally called Comcast and asked them to move me back to Double Play and re-activated my old modem, the trusty Surfboard, and haven't had an internet connection issue since.During this whole ordeal I was on the phone with Comcast at least 10 times, for a total of 3.5 hours, not including the couple hours trying to troubleshoot, power cycle, etc.Now that I think of it, I recall in the past having Netgear modems before my Surfboard and had to RMA them every 6-12 months because they would crap out. After a power cycle they'd work for a bit, then go back to spotty internet. Seems like they never fixed those issues even after all these years. If you've made it this far, you must also be a glutton for punishment. Please don't punish yourself by buying this modem. Learn from my experience and pass on this one.
title: My poor family suffered because of this device.

author: AceDanW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2018
review_content: After buying a new 4K TV I realized that the ISP's modem/router combo with built in wifi wasn't cutting it. So I opted to get a new modem and a new router so that I could have better control of the devices.  This device was easy enough to set up. Once I installed it I tried to use Comcast's useless self install feature. It kept asking me if I wanted to bring over the old wifi settings as if this were a router. So it wouldn't let me specify that it's just a modem. So I had to call support directly. I had the guy change me over in their system (he commented that this is a great modem and that lots of customers are getting them) and then I waited the usual 10-15 minutes for it to start working. So far I've had it over a month and it hasn't needed a single reboot. Download speeds from Comcast are rated at 250Mb's but with this modem my speed test hits about 300 every time.
title: So I opted to get a new modem and a new router so that I could have better control of the devices

author: Amazon25 Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2018
review_content: Didn't work... Xfinity said it was connected, they could read the modem remotely,  but I had no internet access.Since this Modem was almost $200, I had high hopes.Netgear does not make it easy to contact them.  And without active internet, it is difficult to find the support phone number.Netgear is a bad company to deal with, and if their products do not work out of the box, or develop a future problem, there is no help (other than, reboot, restart, unplug, unpower... then do it all again).  I returned it for refund (Thanks Amazon).This is my second cable product from Netgear that did not work. I will not touch Netgear again; there are too many other great products.  The Motorola modem I bought subsequently worked perfectly. AND for 1/2 price.
title: Netgear does not make it easy to contact them

author: DooWop51219
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2018
review_content: Stopped working after 5 months. When I called Netgear for technical support, they wanted to charge me $140 to fix it over the phone or replace the item!!! Apparently the warranty is only 3 months, otherwise they'll charge you this ridiculous amount of money if you need help. The rep was very adamant about taking my credit card information and I finally had enough and just hung up. That must be where they make up for the cheap price. Cheap price for a cheap product.
title: Cheap price for a cheap product

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2018

Outside of the return period and now I'm stuck with a paperweight. The technician also warned me against Netgear modems too, he said they tend to fail earlier. I do NOT recommend getting this you can get cheaper more reliable modems (Arris). Thanks Netgear for disappointing me, you've lost a fan.
title: Stopped working after 2 months

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2018

I would restart the modem and it would work okay for awhile and start acting up again. All morning it has been working for about 15 mins and then it’s down. I’m glad that I forgot to turn in the modem I had been renting from my ISP. I hooked it up and have not had any trouble. I am so disappointed in this modem. I am normally a Netgear fan but this has been nothing but trouble. I do more streaming than anything and I have work I have to do on my iPad a lot and this is unacceptable.

Our internet speeds are where they are supposed to be.Stop renting your modem and buy it!As for technical stuff I have no idea what any of it is without googling something.I paired it with a LINKSYS EA7300 wireless router and am now enjoying way better connectivity.

title: Cheap price for a cheap product

author: hoytlington
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2018
review_content: Like most people reviewing the Netgear CM1000, I was swapping out the Comcast Xfinity supplied modem after recently upgrading to their Gigabit plan.I did a little research before hand and found that the previous model (cm700) and a lot of other Docsis 3.1 modems manufactured in 2017 were defective due to the reliance on an Intel-based chipset known as the “Puma 6”. Before ordering, I got detailed technical specs and found the CM1000 uses a broadcom chipset, thus removing any concerns.There’s really not much to say other than:Easiest modem swap ever.Total time spent installing the new modem: 5 minutes.Product manual comes with a list of modem activation URLs for both Xfinity and Cox on the back of the manual (I didn’t need it, however).No issues, no loss in connectivity, no loss in throughput. Just like it should be!
title: Easiest cable modem replacement ever

author: Moon Stumpp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2018
review_content: Upgrading service, and moving, thought I would go all out with a new Cable Modem, and new wireless router.  Got the CM1000 for the modem and the Orbi for wireless.  The Orbi has been great, the CM1000 has been crap. Worked for about 10 days, then went into a constant restart cycle.  Restart, connect, work for about 30-60 seconds, restart, connect...  You get the picture.  Oh, well, just get a replacement from Amazon makes it easy.  Which Amazon did, it was easy, got a new CM1000, while this one connects for a longer period (about 2 minutes), and then disconnects, but won't restart and reconnect, just disconnect.  I have had other modems on the line working just fine, but not the CM1000.  Not sure what the issue with these are, but I am looking for a refund this time.  Hopefully amazon will let me, without the original box, if not, then I just wasted $159 on a piece of crap.
title: What a piece of crap?

author: Kate Rose Tyler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2018
review_content: I bought this modem with high hopes. we have a 4-year-old Netgear Nighthawk router for our 4-computer and 2-xbox gaming household. it's held up perfectly and still functions as well as the day we got it.this modem, not so much.I should have listened to the 50+ other reviewers who lamented about the modem working for 1-3 months and then continuously dropping connection, necessitating a power cycle/restart. ours did the same thing. we power cycled it four times and it worked between every power cycle for about 10 minutes, then would drop connection again. the same exact thing everyone else was complaining about.we are a house of 4 online gamers (me less so, I mostly stream Netflix/Hulu and play Nintendo consoles, but I occasionally join the online fray). 3 of us built our own custom gaming machines and we pay for fast internet (Spectrum in San Diego is great, aside from Cox but they're not available in our area of SD). I don't want to sound like a snob, but we know what we're doing when it comes to computers and wireless devices.this modem gets VERY HOT. we didn't have it in an enclosed space, it was free-standing on an open shelf. not smothered at all. it was hot within the first half an hour of us plugging it in for the first time. we suspect that the heating problem fries one a component inside the modem that controls the signal. I myself don't know a whole lot about modems, but I suspect what's malfunctioning is either the modulator or the demodulator (incidentally where the name modem comes from; MODulator and DEmodulator, swap the letters D & E), the parts that turn the signal you get from your ISP into data your computer can read, thus giving it its connection, and vice versa.if you buy this modem, it will eventually fail. we turned it on for the first time on May 31st, and it failed yesterday, July 9th. Netgear normally makes fantastic devices, our AC3200 Netgear Nighthawk router has served us well for four years. eventually we'll have to buy a new one but four years is a long time for a router and I attribute its longevity and ability to handle massive amounts of traffic for four years straight to its superior technology and build. I highly recommend the Nighthawk routers, they are great.we had to bust out our old Arris one and I am on the hunt for a replacement for this Netgear one. the Arris one is doing a fine job for now. my bf originally had it for his Cox connection where we used to live and it served him well. he plays games like DOTA 2, Fortnite, League of Legends, Rocket League etc so he needs a good connection. we have two people hardwired to our internet using our router as a switch to support the dual ethernet connections since most standard consumer modems only have one ethernet port.run far away from this modem. the second star is ONLY because while the modem was alive, it performed perfectly. if not for the fatal overheating flaw and subsequent hardware fail, this modem would be fantastic. it allowed us 240mbps down with our 200mbps plan from Spectrum.
title: be cautious when buying this modem - heed the warnings from the rest of us

author: Bruno Berchieri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
review_content: Long story (about 6 hours long, actually...) short:Had a perfectly functional setup of Motorola modem/NetGear router until we decided to replace our reliable SurfBoard with this product.This modem works - don't get me wrong. But not only did Xfinity take over an hour to get it registered and up and running (a process that usually takes 5 minutes), but as soon as you try and connect a router to this you'll realize it doesn't work.I'm sure it's SUPPOSED to work.. but it sure didn't. Mind you, we were connecting it to a Nighthawk NetGear router. After spending 3 hours with NetGear on tech support they finally dropped the pearl that "..your router must be broken."After dismissing them, plugging back the old modem, calling Xfinity again (..and, voila, having the modem up and running in literally 2 minutes...) BEHOLD, my friends, the miracle - as our router RISES FROM THE DEAD, and works flawlessly as it always had before.As far as I'm aware, until someone posts a review that dictates this modem works with routers my personal experience is that it doesn't. Even if it does, and we got a defective unit, a two hundred and thirty dollar modem that took 6 hours of tech support to simply fail miserably at being a modem is probably not worth your time.BUYER BEWARE.
title: It Doesn't Work.

author: john lumpkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2018
review_content: When I 1st ordered this modem I was just looking to upgrade my current modem and move away from the supplied modem by Spectrum, without checking into the capabilities of Spectrum's local internet. To my dismay when the device arrived and I opened the container, on the outside of the box it clearly states its not certified to work on Spectrum ISP. Long story short, was the issue of DOCSIS 3.1 vs DOCSIS 3.0 capabilities and only after studying the issue, I found that Spectrum has not certified ANY DOCSIS 3.1 modems. But this modem not only does DOCSIS 3.1 it automatically checks for 3.0 or 3.1 and defaults to what is needed. When I contacted Spectrum to change over to the new modem it took less than 5 minutes and I was up and rocking. So far, no glitches!
title: When I 1st ordered this modem I was just looking ...

author: Enrique Vargas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2018
review_content: If you're here looking to see if this works with Optimum, you're probably in the same boat that I am in. I've been with Optimum for over 15 years and never ever paid modem fees, then last month I get the bill and Bam, I'm now being charged for it. I called probably like you did, stayed on the phone for 50 minutes, just to be told that it was something that they had to do... Which meant that it was nothing I could do. So the second I was off the phone I came to Amazon to find the right modem that will indeed work with Optimum and this one does and not only does it work, but it's 300 times better than the one that optimum offered. I have the 400 speed package which in the highest that they offer for the Bronx. I was getting no more than 355 on a good day and once I connected this modem I was getting 455, and even the customer service agent was shocked and let me say this, it has been consistently giving me those numbers. Netflix and my Amazon TV has been working without delays or those slight annoying hiccups, and everything has been working so much smoothers when it comes to streaming and also a major notice of improvement on my Xbox one x which for some reason would lag even with the speed I am getting, so it was a headache to play state of decay. Not it works so smoothly, so I highly recommend this modem completely. Don't hesitate , this is the one to get
title: Works with Optimum and works well

author: Richard3107
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2018
review_content: A 16x4 modem at this price?  You bet I wanted to like it, but it wasn't meant to be.  The first three weeks were great with speed tests averaging about 190 Mbps on my 150 Mbps Comcast plan, but then one evening it tanked down to 6 Mbps.  A full system reboot produced no change, so I reinstalled my old Motorola SB6121 and the speed was back up to about 148 Mbps.  There are a lot of reports about the heat the CM500 produces, and mine was definitely getting warmer than I liked, even though it sat in a very well ventilated spot on the top of my desk.  I can't say for certain that the excessive heat was the problem, but the small amount of vent openings in the center do not seem adequate at all.  I love my Nighthawk router, but Netgear needs to go back to drawing board if they want to stay in the modem business.Other Thoughts: I did not like the small status lights.  I could only see them when looking directly at the front.  They are invisible when viewed from even the slightest angle.
title: I Really Wanted To Like This Modem

author: Never too old!
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2020
review_content: I was so excited to see this modem.  It was a modem that had 4 ethernet ports!  What a solution to my home network.  The older construction of my home requires hardwired connections to be reliable internet service.  I have a finished basement whose walls are concrete, so the wifi doesn't work well and if there is any load needed for processing or game play, it HAS to be hardwired.  So here I thought I had the solution!  I could take the main lines we use and connect them to this modem (4 ports: 3 computers and then the router be placed in the other room).  What a solution to the wifi integrity to have the router in the another, more centralized room of the house and then be able to supply wifi to phones, tablets and laptops as well as hardwire a computer, DVD player or other device.  NOPE, you CAN'T use the other ports that way.  You MUST plug the router in the first port and  then NONE of the other hardwired cables would work in the other 3 ports!  So why did I pay for the other 3 ports??  They are functional for something, I'm not sure what, but they DO NOT allow a simple hardwired computer to be attached to them.  So I'm back to my original set up with the router right next to the modem and everything plugged into the router and then have to have another router in the other room.  The advertisement leads you to believe it is a true modem/router in one.  I DO HOPE YOU READ THIS BEFORE YOU BUY IT THINKING YOU COULD DO THE SAME.Having said that, the modem works great.  It pushes though the faster speeds I am getting from the cable company and the new  router I also got (also a Netgear product) is fabulous.  It's an AC1750 and the wifi range is very good compared to the other router I had.  It would have been fantasitic if I could have located this router in the other central room of my home!  Oh well.In closing, in my situation, I should have just went with a one port modem and saved a few bucks. Since the other 3 ports on this modem aren't functional for what I needed it to do, the ports are pretty useless to me.If anyone knows a way to get other hardwired computers to be attached to this modem, I would appreciate the advise.  I'll keep reading and see if I can figure out the function of the other 3 ports.
title: Why are there 4 ethernet ports? BUT can't hardwire other devices to them.

author: Cal Man
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2018
review_content: I purchased this modem to use on the Comcast XFinity network, as an upgrade to an older Motorola modem that no longer supports my current subscription speed.  I hooked the modem up to the network, precisely as prescribed in the installation manual, but could not get the uplink channel locked in so that I could connect to the activation site.  I power-cycled the modem multiple times, but still no success so I called XFinity to see if they could establish the channel from their side.  They tried sending signals to the modem for over an hour, but finally gave up.  There was no problem with the network connection since we were quickly able to re-connect my older modem.  I tried calling Netgear's tech support line a couple of times... the first time waiting 75 min on-hold while I only moved from position "nine" in the queue to number "five".  I tried again mid-day, and found myself waiting without movement at number "15" in the queue.  I finally gave up and am returning the defective modem.
title: Didn't Connect to XFinity Network -- Poor Netgear Tech Support

author: RyeLusion
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
review_content: Most of you who follow tech related news are aware that this product contains the Puma 6 chipset from intel. Intel Puma 6 chip has been shown to have some latency issues with  this and other 32 x 8 modems. The chipset just isn't up performing 32 x 8 tasks. A class action lawsuit has been filed and its clear the issue still exists. In short you don't want this modem because it will be slowing down your internet connection relative to other, better designed modems. This isn't a recommendation against netgear, many netgear routers don't have this issue, and other manufacturers used this bad chipset as well. But do yourself a favor and check if the device you are looking at has an intel puma 6 chipset before buying, you will save yourself a ton of headache and have faster internet response times if you opt for one that doesnt have this chipset in its specifications.
title: Intel puma 6 chipset on CM700 increases latancy 10X over CM600. Dont Buy this!

author: DaxxRuckus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2018
review_content: Great DOCSIS 3.1 modem.  I upgraded from  an Arris 3.0 when Cox Gigablast became available in my neighborhood.  With this modem I'm getting almost full gigabit download speeds!  It was cheaper than any other brand, and Amazon delivered it quickly.  Highly recommended!
title: Great DOCSIS 3

author: Richard
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2018
review_content: While the box states this will work with any tier on Spectrum/Time Warner's internet plans, upon attempting to register it, I found this to be false. I do not know if the fault lies on TWC/Spectrum's end or Netgear's. After an hour of attempting to get a Spectrum representative to initialize it, we finally got it to recognize it. But only for 60mbps. That's right, according to their system the max they'll allow the CM700 to download is 60mbps. This is a real shame considering I bought this to take full advantage of my new 200mbps connection. I was replacing an arris Surfboard, which served me well for the last 5 years. I thought Netgear would certainly be a better product, so I figured this would be an upgrade. I've learned my lesson, I went to walmart and bought a new Arris Surfboard and now I get full 200+mbps and a lot less headache.
title: Does not work correctly with Time Warner / Spectrum

author: ken
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2019
review_content: Great cable modem, works with my Spectrum Gig. Note it's only a modem and not a router. FWIW, I'm not using the bonding or multiple IP address features. Remember to restart the thing after setup. It wouldn't otherwise connect to my wifi router. That is, read the quick start guide!
title: Works with Spectrum Gig for me

author: Kim L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: I would give this zero stars if that was an option.  We have had this modem for less than a year and it completely stopped working.  I called Netgear (because it says there is a 1 year warranty) but they won't even talk to me unless I pay $89 for a 6 month support contract.  Apparently although they advertise a 1 year warranty, all tech support stops at 90 days.  That's almost half of what I paid for the defective modem in the first place!  Why on earth would I pay you more to confirm that your product is a piece of junk??  Highly dissatisfied.  I will never purchase another Netgear product.  The customer service is TERRIBLE and they completely misrepresent the warranty and their willingness to support their customers.  DO NOT BUY.  Consider yourself warned.
title: HUGE MISTAKE - Never buying NETGEAR again!

author: Cary M. Soriano
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2019
review_content: Upgraded my xfinity plan to gigabit speeds. If you have the triple play (TV, Internet, voice) plan with XFINITY and you are excited about not paying rental fees to Xfinity, this is your only modem choice for now until another manufacturer can make a better device. First unit I ordered came really fast. Setup is super easy. I provisioned it using xfinity.com/activate and was able to enter my account information and have the automated system do its job. I was up and running in less than 10 minutes after plugging it in. It's important to first plug a cat6 cable directly from the modem to a test computer to see the connection speeds. This first unit I got was extremely disappointing since I was expecting close to gigabit speeds. It was hitting a peak maximum of 200Mbps and my OLD data plan was able to get 400Mbps from the previous modem that was only DOCSIS 3.0. I had an xfinity technician come over to verify all the signals and connections and validated that the incoming signal was strong enough for gigabit speed. He isolated the issue to this Netgear CM1150v modem. I contacted NETGEAR themselves and they had me go through the same routine troubleshooting. Soft reset. Hard reset. Nothing worked. There is no firmware to update since that is not even an option on this device. I have initiated a replacement/return with Amazon. I will update once I get the new unit.UPDATE: Received the replacement unit and all is well now. The first unit was definitely defective.
title: Read other reviews. Unfortunately the only DOCSIS 3.1 modem that supports xfinity voice

author: VB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: I purchased this product to be able to use Xfinity internet at 60MB.  specks said it should work.  I got about 7mb down and .7mb up.  Comcast came out to see what was up and debug as I was a new user.  New cable ends new connectors etc.  Nothing fixed the problem.  As a last try, we hooked up a rental xfinity cable modem/wifi router and performance went to 70MB down and 7mb up.  I hooked my old ABUS wifi router to their modem and still get the 70mb down.  Unfortunately, I missed the return window.
title: DOES NOT WORK RIGHT WITH XFINITY INTERNET

author: bmal1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2018
review_content: My old modem was deemed no longer compatible with Comcast Xfinity service. I bought this cable modem so I can get higher speeds and it won't go out of date for while. I had to activate the modem over the phone w/Comcast support as activating it through the Comcast website didn't work for me. It was an easy process. After installing and activating the modem I wasn't getting the speeds I expected. I did a factory reset on my router and then I was getting the speed I was paying for. If you are not getting the speeds you expect, start by connecting your pc directly to the modem and run a speed test. If you are getting the expected speed directly from the modem then the problem is within your network.  Also do not enable any QoS/ Traffic Manager features in your router. Others have mentioned that it runs hot. I have the modem in the basement where it is cool so it is warm but not hot. I am happy with it so far.
title: Works great.

author: JPS500
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
review_content: I bought this modem in April when I upgraded the speed on my cable internet from Cox.  It was easy to install and it worked fine for eight months.  Then it stopped working--no internet.  I reset the modem with the on/off button; no internet.  I unplugged the modem, waited a few minutes, plugged it back in, no internet.  Power light comes on, download light comes on, but upload light just flashes rapidly.  So Cox comes out to check on it and all the cable lines inbound are good, so they install a new Motorola Surfboard and my internet works fine.  I go online to find the warranty coverage and see I  am covered through April 2019, send in to get a Return Authorization and get an email back that "our experts are working on it" and they will revert.  I hear nothing for twelve days so I call them today, they have my case number but they won't authorize a return to confirm that the modem is broken.  They want me to disconnect my working modem and test the old one.  Not what I would call good customer service.  I won't be buying Netgear again and I would recommend you not either.
title: Terrible Warranty Coverage

author: Scott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2019
review_content: The setup of this device was complete nightmare because neither Netgear nor Comcast provided two crucial pieces of information:• You can use only 1 of the 4 Ethernet ports on this modem. The other 3 ports are apparently for some ethereal future use. Probably vaporware that will never materialize.• Each time you switch the single device you can have linked to this modem, you must completely power down the modem for at least 10 seconds and restart the modem (some call this process recycling) or the device will not obtain an IP address.Lacking this information caused me to spend multiple hours on many calls with smart and kind Xfinity agents featuring an amazing diversity of difficult-to-understand accents. I just wanted to set this modem up like my old one; with one router and my work laptop directly wired to it.It took three long phone calls just to get the modem fully registered on my Xfinity account and to get the Xfinity Voice feature working. But no matter what we tried, the modem we linked to the router failed to obtain an IP address. My work laptop got an IP address, but the modem did not. After a little online research, I figured that my 3½-year-old modem must have gone the way of all the earth. So I ran out and bought a new modem, only to find that it also failed to obtain an IP address.While some of the Xfinity agents claimed deep knowledge of this modem, at no point did any of them seem to realize that only one Ethernet port could be used at a time. Online discussion threads suggest that many have spent hours on the phone with Netgear to discover this crucial information. As soon as I realized this was an issue, I disconnected my laptop so that only the router was linked to the modem, but the router still failed to obtain an IP address.Xfinity ended up arranging for a technician to come to my house, but another Xfinity agent later called to see if we could fix the issue without a physical visit. After that didn't work, I finally found an obscure discussion thread online that said you had to recycle the modem after switching devices or the new device would not obtain an IP address. Sure enough, following this procedure caused the modem to obtain an IP address. I kept my old modem and returned the new one.Despite the horrible process of getting the modem fully functional for our needs, I have to say that it works great. Our download speeds have literally doubled. If this modem lasts more than four years, as did our last one, we will have saved nearly $300 by owning rather than renting the cable modem.So go ahead and buy this modem for your Xfinity needs. But directly wire only your main networking device (router) to it. If you ever switch routers, make sure to fully recycle the modem so that the router will obtain an IP address. Many Boffins died to bring you this information.
title: Warning: You can use only 1 of the 4 Ethernet ports on this device at a time

author: walter harriman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2018
review_content: After purchasing this modem it ran good for 4 months it then failed to connect to upstream. called Comcast they sent a tech who tested line and confirmed the line good. after swapping modem with one of theirs it connected almost instantly, so I am renting a Comcast modem till I RMA my dead modem with Netgear. This is where the FUN starts. i go to there website to submit a RMA request. ok step 1 create your ticket check, step 2 call this number, wait what where is the email option or electronic option there is none. ok called number ya number 4th in the queue. wait 50 minutes and finally get a person. now we troubleshoot the modem, I tell him that's already been done, no you have to follow the list fine, look never connects. ok then put on hold for 20 minutes to talk to my supervisor. finally there back i as sorry we don't have any replacement modems in are warehouse. we will call you or email you when we get some in stock. goodbye hangs up. so its been 3 weeks now I sent 2 updates to my ticket and i was told to "Hi, Walter, Good day Please give us 24-48 hours to update you regarding the replacement of your unit. Thank you for your patience. Many thanks, Best regards, Jay Netgear Support" then yesterday I get a email asking me to "Rate your NETGEAR Support Experience" I go back to there website to find my ticket closed and I don't have a RMA replacement for my still under warranty item.I try to find any way to contest this closing there is non all it says is "This case has already been closed, please log a new support request if you require further help." so I try to open a new RMA ticket for my modem only to find the system will not except my serial number anymore, so it refuses to create a new ticket. so hear I sit screwed with a warranty item I can not get warranty service replacement on, paying for a Comcast rental modem. wile my expensive paper weight just sits there. does anyone know a way around this Netgear system a email or some way to get something done?
title: Never buy from Netgear again, saying there RMA process is painful is being nice.

author: Mr. Michael C. Hand
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2019
review_content: I am a optimum customer and have the 400GBPS plan with them. Over the past 3 years, using their Arris TM1602A modem, I have been frustrated with buffering, when streaming, slow downloads, etc. speed checking, off and on, I would notice speeds as low as in the 100s gbps up to the 300s. I never had hit 400gbps from what I observed. From the provider I would get excuses from copper exposed connectors creating antennas and draining the function to using too many devices to wireless products and so on. I accepted those excuses until I heard a tech person, from a different provider, talking about how their provider throttles the speed in the modems they provide along with monitoring what you use it for... I use it for basic use, from tv shows, live tv and movies (no, not porn) along with gaming and internet use... basic stuff as far as I'm concerned. I do not know if the provider does as I heard, however I wanted to take the chance an see if it is a solution... after all I can always return it with amazon. I did and had a problem. On the modems they install for you, there is this connection between the coax cable and modem, a filter or something. make sure you use it!!! Other than that, make sure your coax cable is not the cheap stuff and you are good to go. I was able to connect by internet (takes a few minutes when new modem connects) with web site address netgear provides. At first the connection is slow - I checked and was told it takes 24-48 hours for full speed for whatever BS reason. Note, if you don't see an improvement soon to a reset on modem (push in button that you need a paperclip for) and restart your router (I use netgear x10) and computer. I saw improvements quickly increase within the 12-24 hour period. Since hook up from 2 days ago this is the numbers I am getting (see picture). I am not a tech geek and was hesitant but this was fairly painless and now I no longer need to lease a provider controlled modem that costs $10 a month that you generally talk to a automated response when you have problems. Now, if you had netgear tech support you will know their tech support has something to be desired with the heavy accent from their support staff... fortunately I rarely needed their help.
title: Better Than Expected!!!

author: No Magic Crystals
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2019
review_content: My Internet Service with Wave Broadband is "High Speed 100" which is 100 Mbps down / 5 Mbps up.My first DOCSIS 3.0 modem I bought was the Linksys CM3024. After doing some online research, due to some technical difficulties using the Linksys,  discovered that there was a severe Latency issue with all Modems using the Intel Puma 6 chip (The Linksys CM3024 uses it).After searching online at places like approvedmodemlist and checking with Amazon technical support (very helpful) I found the Netgear CM500 which doesn't use the Intel Puma 6 chip AND is supported by my ISP.  I returned the CM3024 and bought the CM500.Been running for 2 days now no issues and very happy.ADDITIONAL NOTE:If you are paying for a VPN service through your VPN capable router like the ASUS RT-AC68U you will see a severe drop in your D/L speed. See Picture 2.  I would recommend that if you like the security of using a VPN for surfing, banking etc, and like to stream HD video content on your TV's, Video devices etc,  to set up two routers.The router connected to the Modem  would be the non-VPN one.  All your Video streaming devices would be connected to that router wired/wirelessly. The second VPN router's WAN port would be connected to one of the first router's LAN ports. Your sensitive/secured connections would be via that device.
title: Works as expected on Wave Broadband Washington  state--No Intel Puma 6 Chip

author: TwoLeftFeet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2019
review_content: Major issues! Works, then doesn't work.  Can't support my home network.  Only one ethernet connection allowed at a time? Huh?  Ethernet connected to laptop shuts down the network in the rest of the house, including wifi. Have to unplug and reset entire network each time if I want to use ethernet. Useless!  Told by mfg support that third and fourth ports not supported anyway.  What the heck??  A lot of $$ spent to end up with an expensive paperweight.  Hours with a qualified technician troubleshooting,  tried every option under the sun to get it to work as advertised to no avail.  Bottom line, it's a boat anchor!  You will need another router/modem to get this to work as advertised. Would not recommend.  A great idea poorly executed.
title: Choose something else if you have a choice.

author: Ryan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2020
review_content: This is a decent modem, but it is outclassed in specs and build quality by both the Arris SB8200 and the Motorola MB8600. It is also vulnerable to a critical exploit which can potentially leave your network open to others.I originally chose the CM1000 because I had a great history with my CM600. Throughout the years I owned the CM600, the device never needed reboots, and my signal quality was great. It is currently serving as a modem at my parents home.Now that I have gigabit internet, I needed a more powerful modem. The CM1000 disappointed me with the build quality. The base is made of plastic and feels very cheap and wobbly. I also think having a thin and wide plastic base looks less than appealing, but most people won’t be looking at their modem, so it isn’t a huge dealbreaker. The CM1000 has lesser specs than the competing 3.1 modems however, and this was very noticeable. The modem homepage loaded extremely slow, and during the 2 weeks that the modem was working, the connection was not always perfect.I gave up on the modem after having completely lost connection to my isp. Upon further research into troubleshooting, I found out that this modem is susceptible to a vulnerability known as “Cable Haunt.” This is a critical security exploit which can potentially give an attacker control of your modem. This issue is made worse due to the fact that firmware updates are pushed out by ISP’s, and not every internet provider will update modem firmware. I was stuck with a modem that wasn’t currently operational, and one that had a security exploit that wouldn’t be fixed as my ISP (Suddenlink) does not push out firmware updates.My solution was to switch to the MB8600, which has much better build quality, a surge protector on the coaxial input, more RAM, and is not currently listed as being vulnerable to the Cable Haunt exploit.
title: CM1000 modem

author: Trevor Williams
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2020
review_content: There was another review which pretty much echoes my experience except that my modem started to fail just after the three-month mark. It's a real shame because in the 10+ years I've purchased my own modems (just two prior to this one) I've never had one fail before, let alone fail in just three months of use.Everything worked exactly as expected from when I received it on January 18th, 2020. It was only a few days ago when, out of nowhere, the modem just stopped working as intended. In summary, it could download content, but uploading became very inconsistent, thus making video conferencing all but impossible. On top of that, the overall connection became spotty at best, working for a few hours before completely staying dead for another few hours.Given the shelter-in-place order my state is in right now, not being able to effectively work from home without a reliable internet connection was completely unacceptable.Of course I blamed Comcast first.A technician came to my home yesterday (very helpful, knowledgeable, and a DIY PC builder like myself) to inspect the hard line from the street, the line from the box on the side of my house to where it directly connects to the modem, and the modem itself. They upgrading some cabling in the box, but other than that the signal strength for them was strong and healthy. After several repeated attempts to get the modem to work, the conclusion was that the modem itself was at fault. After weighing the options and examining the evidence, I decided to accept their XB6 modem as a replacement.I'm REALLY disappointed at my Netgear CM1200 modem crapping out, and so early into its life. Though I haven't rented a modem in a long time, I'd rather do that right now than risk spending another $200 on a Netgear product that might die within a quarter.
title: Died After Three Months

author: Brenin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2018
review_content: I purchased this to replace an aging Motorola/Arris SB6141 after I moved to the Comcast Xfinity Gigabit Internet tier. After setting it up and a quick call to Comcast/Xfinity to have it added to my account and an activation signal sent, I was good to go. Works as intended and I am getting the max download/upload speeds advertised so I couldn't be happier, not to mention no rental fee. Word of caution if you are an existing Comcast/Xfinity customer replacing your modem, don't bother with the instructions that mention to visit xfinity.com/activate to activate your equipment, it will most likely fail at the end right out of the box. To save yourself time and aggravation, do the following:1. Remove your old modem from the coaxial and attach the new CM1000 modem.2. Power it on and wait for the first 4 LED lights to go solid green (there are 5, but you won't see the fifth until you attach it to a NIC or home router)3. Attach the included Cat 5E cable to the back and plug it into a laptop or nearby PC4. Call 1-800-934-6489, go through the prompts until it connects you to the Comcast/Xfinity activation support agent.5. Say you would like to replace the modem on your account, answer the account verification questions, and have your modem MAC address handy.6. Provide the MAC address and wait for them to add it to your account and send the activation signal. They may ask you which version of the CM1000 you have, in which case answer the 1AZNAS. Once they confirm and send the activation signal, you will see the modem recycle itself a couple times before settling back on four solid green LED lights.7. The support agent should have you test the connectivity after that and if all went well, you should be up and running.8. (If you have a home router) Turn the router off/unplug it, and attach the Cat 5E/6 cable from the cable modem. Power cycle the cable modem one more time and wait for it to come fully back online with the four solid green lights. Turn on/plug the router power back in and let it fully come online as well. At this point, you will see the 5th green LED light on the modem indicating NIC connectivity and you should be good to go.NOTE: Once they properly send the correct bootfile/configuration to your modem the first time, any subsequent activations/provisioning (for instance if you move or swap modems then swap back) seem to work fine off of xfinity.com/activate. It is that out of the box initial configuration that fails with the automated setup.
title: No hassle setup and money well spent

author: C. Pilson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2019
review_content: Edit: lowered rating to one-star on 20 March, 2019. That's less than six months after I purchased this device. It runs HOT. Really really hot. Really super mega ultra hot. It's standing upright, has airflow, and has a good 3" of space around the unit on all sides, and 12 feet of space above it. I suspect this is the device that has thrown my network stack into the crapper lately, this is my weak link. Shame, too, as the old ARRIS/Motorola SURFboard works and just kept on working. I removed that from production because I was upgrading speeds and needed a DOCSIS 3.1 modem.I WOULD NOT BUY THIS MODEM AGAIN, AND WOULD STRONGLY RECOMMEND AGAINST ITS PURCHASE.It’s always difficult to say if a device providing poor connectivity is due to the vendor (e.g. Cox, Mediacom, etc.) or the hardware.In this case, many of the “whoops, the connection just totally shat itself” events are due to this device.This replaced a Motorola Surfboard, the white one (yeah, that one. 1641?). The Motorola had done yeoman’s service over five years and I was looking to do a technology refresh as well as move to the next DOCSIS point-version for gigabit capability.So I bought this unit.And I wish I hadn’t. Netgear hardware used to be a fairly good choice; if the two units I purchased are any indication, Netgear is on its way out.This device seems to be very happy to trip over its own balls and go head-first into Internet pavement of flashing LEDs regularly.
title: When it works, it’s good. But...

author: That Detroit Guy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2018
review_content: CM1000 - This modem is great. We just cut the cord and decided to up our internet speed to Gigabit for that reason. We had 350 but with multiple UHDTV's and game consoles in the house, it was necessary. Please note, if you buy the CM1000 modem, you need to be sure all of your connections are up to par. You need to be sure to update your entire network wiring or you'll be losing out on some of those megabits.Be sure you have:- Gigabit internet service (if you're going for ~1000 Mbps speed)- A router and/or switch (if applicable to your setup) that supports Gigabit (10/100/1000) speed.- Make sure you have at MINIMUM Cat5e ethernet cable. I'm using Cat6 on everything that's wired in my network.If you setup your network with the correct wiring and equipment then this modem will be a great pickup.
title: CM1000 - This modem is great. We just cut the cord and decided to ...

author: Athena
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2018
review_content: Easy to set up,  highly recommended!  Set it up with Comcast over the phone but for some reason their modem reset didn’t work k so had to get the Comcast guy out to “set it” so we could get Internet . They didn’t charge us but still it’s our time spent. Plus, several days of having to use the Ethernet cable for laptop. Loathe their overseas customer “service”...sneaky liars who offer promos  without full disclosure which falls under unfair and deceptive business practices, it’s against the law ( maybe since their overseas it doesn’t apply?) So, now I say I’m not interested 2-3 times and say goodbye. It’s a bad customer experience.  Comcast makes hand over fist in money and should keep those jobs in America.
title: Highly recommend. Not Comcast however.

author: GR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2020
review_content: Absolutely highest performance internet modem ever....  extremely smart with the highest internet multi GIG modem technology chipset... I have benchmarked it multiple times and I have been very impressed with the performance and the results ...
title: Extremely high performance internet modem in the market available

author: MS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2018
review_content: Worked fine for 2 months now I am rebooting almost daily to get my rated internet speeds.  20mb/.5 before reboot, 175/6 after reboot.  31 channels locked down / 4 channels locked going up.  Since I can fix my issue by rebooting the router I know it's not a ISP problem.  For the price and the reputation of NetGear I expected much better.
title: Was great to start, but didn't last

author: WildBob
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2020
review_content: So i run this cable modem with LACP enabled (two 1Gig  connections from the modem to my routers WAN ports to give me more bandwidth) to my new Netgear RAX80 WIFI 6 router. I thought I was having issues with the router as my download speeds would slow from 1024mbps to 12-20mbps over a 24hr period. After a reboot the speeds would be normal. I returned the RAX80 but the issues persisted. It turns out this is an identified problem with the firmware version Xfinity has deployed to the CM1150V cable modems (you are dependent on your ISP for FW updates to the modem) V2.02.04 is the newest version Xfinity/Comcast deploys and it has a bug relating to LACP.**UPDATE 1/14/2020**I disabled LACP and with the single connection to my router the speeds stopped slowing to a crawl. While I wish I could use the features I paid for, Netgear has updated their firmware,  but Comcast/Xfinity hasn't approved it yet, but I cant blame Netgear for that.
title: Waiting for Xfinity to deploy updated firmware. V2.02.04 has issue with LACP.

author: Anthony Clemens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2020
review_content: I purchased the CM1200 in August 2020 and received it 8/8/2020.  I attempted to connect the device at home as it was replacing the CM500.  I have an AC1750 Netgear router that was connected to the CM500 and is now connected to the CM1200.  I spent 5 hours the first night working with Netgear and my ISP (Comcast) to setup the device correctly; I was unable to use the activate link and had to call Comcast.  While on the phone, Comcast stated because it's a Netgear product, Netgear would have to provide the firmware.  However, Netgear's knowledge base states Comcast actually pushes the firmware.  It started to feel like I was in the middle between Comcast and Netgear.  This should have been an easy experience - plug and play - just like I have done with many other computer hardware.Once the device was setup, it worked well for about a week.  The following Sunday I contacted Comcast again because I no longer was getting internet service.  Comcast could not see the modem.  We went through normal troubleshooting of a power cycle of both the modem and router.  Internet service resumed.  A little later, Comcast could not see the modem again.  Went through the same steps and it was back.Comcast sent a technician out on 8/18/2020.  They changed connections outside of my place.  Also pushed all the service to one cable connection in my place; all other cable wall outlets do not have cable as I'm trying to ensure all the service is going to where I am connecting my internet and TV (I've been in this place for 4 years and did not have this problem previously until recently).The following Sunday I contacted Comcast again and went through the same steps.  The following days I had to restart my modem each morning because I no longer had wifi when I got up to start work.  I contacted Comcast 8/27/2020 to further discuss the issue.  The first time we went through the normal steps of trying to restart the modem, unplug the modem, attempt to make a connection from Comcast to the modem, etc.  Internet service came back... for an hour.  An hour later I contacted Comcast again and they pointed me to Netgear.  Now I really feel like I'm between Comcast and Netgear and no one taking ownership of the problem.After speaking with Comcast on 8/27/2020, I entered a support case with Netgear.  I contacted them on 8/28/2020 because Netgear apparently does not reach out when a case is entered, it is up to the user to contact them after creating a case online.  At 4 PM on 8/28, the Netgear technician had me reset the modem, unplug the modem, unplug the router and then reconnect everything.  I explained I do this on a daily basis, but went along.  When this was done, internet service returned... as expected.  The tech said to monitor the internet for the next couple days to see if the problem persists.  I told him I know what's going to happen and that I will be contacting Netgear again before a couple days ends.  I asked if they could just send a replacement because I've been dealing with this issue for 3 weeks at this point, and he said just monitor the internet service.At 8 PM on 8/28 (4 hours after reaching Netgear) I was on the phone again with Comcast because internet service was non-existent.  At 8:30 PM I began my hour long hold with Netgear following up on my open case stating what I told the prior technician that I would be calling Netgear back because I would no longer have internet service.  We went through similar steps, however this time the technician had me change a setting on the router.I'm expecting I'll once again be contacting Comcast and Netflix on either 8/29 or 8/30 because the internet is no longer working for me.At this point, I'm caught between Comcast stating that I'm using my own device and they can't support that, and Netgear saying I have 90 days on my service warranty.  Meanwhile, I have intermittent internet issues causing me to use my mobile hotspot to work.I will say Netgear tech support has been pleasant once I get through the queue, but I've been on hold 30 to 60 minutes each time I call and then another 30 to 60 minutes troubleshooting.  I've also had to repeat many details along the way when I call, however, so that's frustrating.I'm hoping this gets resolved, or I'll have to work with Amazon to return the modem and hopefully get a full refund.
title: CM1200 Provides Intermittent Signal - Inconsistent Mpbs, Mostly < 100 Mbps & Frequent < 50 Mpbs

author: mr. sticks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review_content: The only thing likeable about this unit is that for the short time it worked it was decent, however it only lasted five months and then crashed. It lost its connection one day for no apparent reason and I not being a novice went thru every procedure to try and get it to function without success and could not get any help from Amazon or Netgear. Looks like I just blew $160.00 for another paperweight from Netgear and this will indeed be the last as their products do not last.UPDATE: After a week went by after I wrote this I decided to try again because I was just so PO'd because of losing this amt. of money. It took me about  days after sending a several emails and FINALLY I got a reply that asked me to do some tests to see if they could figure out what was wrong that way if they could. After several failures they agreed to replace the unit but I had to pay to ship the bad unit back which I wasn't happy about since it was defective, but apparently it was the only way I was going to be getting a replacement for the bad one. They in my best interest was to send me a BRAND NEW MODEM and was shipped to me free.Bottom line is while they seem to be hard to get a hold of which is something that they should really address, they did the wright thing and sent me a brand new sealed unit that has been working exceptionally well so far. Hopefully it will last longer than the last one which only worked for five months. In any case, thank you Motorola for doing the right thing.
title: Waste of money but changed my mind! Please read!

author: Detailing Man
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2020
review_content: I moved into a new home in early 2020 that is only serviced by Xfinity Comcast. I've always heard bad stories about how Comcast throttles and screws people over. I've been very happy with AT&T the past 20 years, albeit the fastest I could download was at 100Mbps. So I prepared myself for the worst and decided on this CM1200 in hopes of minimizing my dependance on Xfinity.Once it arrived, I plugged in the coax and waited a few minutes. I then hooked up my laptop and began the registration process. After a few speed tests, 800/900 down, I sought to enable Link Aggregation. I mean, what better way to put my new RAX120 to good use?Ports 1&2 were connected respectively from the CM1200 to the RAX120 after configuring link agg in both devices. It took a little longer for the modem to negotiate with Comcast, but it was all green lights after that. Ran a speed test and now I was getting speeds of almost 1200Mbps!After 8 months, I'm happy to report that there have been no major issues. We had several power outages and only once did I have to use the Xfinity self help website to reboot the modem. There were times where I wasn't getting the full 1.2G, but I switched to Cat 6 for the link agg and that seemed to fix it. The downside of this is I've blown past the 1.2 Terabyte data cap in as little as a week. Oh well, first world problems as they say.
title: Use the power of Link Aggregation wisely

author: Bret
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2018
review_content: After trying both the Motorola MB8600 and Arris SB8200, I've concluded this is the best DOCSIS 3.1 modem:Cons:- Its the biggest of the 3- It runs hotter than the Motorola, but less hot than the Arris.  It run acceptably warm- Doesn't have Link Aggregation (LAG) (although you probably don't need it, ISP doesn't support it, or have the networking gear to support it, and even if you do, make sure to benchmark!  LAG isn't aways faster in some configurations).Pros:- Most reliable connection compared to Motorola and Arris.  I was having line issues, of the 3 modems, this one had the least (none) connection issues.  The cable company repaired the issues finally, but this modem was a champ during the period of bad signal.  The arris and Motorola would disconnect constantly and never come back until power cycled.- Cheap!- Best web UI of all modemsIf you want this modem, but are lamenting the lack of LAG, Netgear does have a CM1100 which supports LAG, but its only available at Costco right now.  Womp.
title: Beats out the Motorola MB8600 and Arris SB8200

author: Connor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2020
review_content: I was following the instructions by the top commenters on this product, but those are now over 2 years old now and did not work for me so I thought I would share my experience on exactly what you should do to set this up. Also his instructions talked about connecting an ethernet cord to his laptop and most laptops no longer have that. I tried doing this myself, but I confirmed with the Comcast Agent that you actually need to call Comcast in order to switch modems.1. Call 1-800-COMCAST and try your best to get to an agent(I know this is tough with all the ridiculous questions)2. Once you get to an agent tell them you want to deactivate your Comcast modem and setup your own.3. They will have to first deactivate your current modem so it is helpful if it is still connected.4. Once they deactivate the old one they will send you a text asking for permission to update your bill. Congrats you are now saving $14 a month!5.  After you unplug the old modem and plug in yours you will have to wait until all the lights are solid green.They will also ask for the MAC code of your new modem to add it to your account so have that ready.6. Now you can connect your router and turn it on and test to see if your wifi is working. You should not have to reset anything on your router and all previous networks/passwords should remain unchanged.6. **Tip** Have your laptop available to test if your internet is working. Once you verify it is working, go to speedtest.net and see what kind of megabytes per second (Mbps) download you are getting. You actually pay more for this. I was paying for the 300mbps option but only getting 80mbps! I told the agent this and she did some reconfiguring and then I tested it again after and I now had 350mbps!7. The comcast agent failed to mention to me that I had to return my old modem. I asked about it before hanging up and she confirmed I did have to return it at the closest store or I would be charged! Don't forget and good luck!
title: New Instructions for Comcast/Xfinity Customers

author: vendors
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2019
review_content: Tis product sucks. Netgear used to be a reliable product. I have preferred the for the longest time over their rivals. It does not hit its max speed only about 60-70% if your lucky. While the say you can bond two ports together when you go to their website they tell you it is not possible. I have tried 3 modems to verify that one was not broken.There are many variable in achieving the max throughput. Your router on the back really is a major bandwidth problem. With a Gig router and this modem, I would achieve speeds of 300 mbps on a 1 gig Comcast service. Totally unacceptable. Remove the router from the equation and I maxed out at about 750mbps.Comcast Modem achieves 960-980 mbps, provides a builtin router for both wired and wireless connectivity. THIS IS NOT A COMMERCIAL FOR COMCAST by any means.
title: BUYER BEWARE!!! - The products sucks and NEVER achieves max speed -

author: Rob
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2019
review_content: If you bought the 1Gbps speed from comcast and bought a Arris Surfboard......then you know the pain. I was lead to buy a surfboard of 1.4Gbps but its false advertisement and isnt docsis 3.1. You need docsis 3.1 modem for 1Gbps, and this netgear was the missing piece!Install was easy, I plugged it right up and called the Xfinity agents up and this sweet agent did all the work after she put in the MAC address and Model number on my account to activate, then unplugged the router and BOOOM! 1GBPS!Speed test confirms speed and im happy I now have what I paid for! EASY PEASY!!!!!UPDATE AS OF 3/21/2019********so the box didnt work consistently it seems. but it could still be xfinity! we had 1gbps straight line from the pole but then it went to 50 mbps download and 40 upload and stayed there forever. we tried isolating the router and speed testing the modem and still same speeds. xfinity guy tries to get my stuff to work for hours but no go. new xb6 modem installed for 15 a month and all my services work. who knows. maybe they secretly forced me into this as a conspiracy theory or the modem just didnt work! hahhaa. well who knows but right now my speed tests are 980 Mbps! im happy but all in all.......BUY THIS WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT IT MAY NOT WORK WITH TP LINK AC2300 router since i failed with that setup and my modem coulda been bad aswell. Try it and be prepared to return if need be! Goodluck!
title: UPDATE 2 days LATER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

author: rblaw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2020
review_content: Comcast notified me that my modem was not compatible with its latest high speed internet signal. It advised that my service could be four times as fast with a new modem. I wasn’t sure I needed any more speed, but I shelled out the $152 for the Netgear CM1000 which had been recommended by Comcast. Although mindful of the reviewer who described a 5 minute setup, I picked a time for installation when it wouldn’t be a hassle to be without wifi for an hour. That proved to be a very low estimate.There were instructions on how to set things up for Comcast without talking to anyone. Those instructions were bogus. I got part way into the process when I got a message that things didn’t work, and that I should call a Comcast number. I messed around with the phone robot telling me to try again, but finally made contact with a person. She said she had to delete the registration of the existing modem, before she could register the new modem. After that process I had no Internet reception. After trying various things I got very fast (almost 1,000 MBPS) service on a computer hooked directly to the modem. Then I connected the modem to my Nighthawk X6  R8000 router. After multiple reboots, I got reception via the router. Wired directly to the router, the computer shosed a speed of about 500 MBPS. But the wifi speed was a pitiful 45, slower than my reception with the old modem. After over an hour on the phone with the Comcast woman, I told her I had done enough for one day. I would work on the router the next day.On the next day, I put another hour into the setup. Based on recommendations I had read, I did factory resets on the router and installed the latest firmware. There was no improvement in wifi speed. Since I seldom use a computer directly connected to the router, I have received no improvement from the new moden. I sure I will blow some time doing more messing with the router. From what I have read, that model should be able to handle a very high speed signal and then provide reasonably fast wifi.
title: Nightmare

author: K.W.P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
review_content: I picked the CM700 to replace an aging and increasingly unstable SB6141, and because it was explicitly listed as an "approved" modem for Spectrum service. Spectrum had no issues provisioning it (took about 5 minute over the phone to do for an active service), and my observed speeds went from 160 down / 22 up to 230 down / 23 up. Hooked it up to my Nighthawk X4 and everything is fine and stable with a dozen or more wireless devices connected, simultaneously streaming video, doing other work, etc.As of the time of writing for this review, this is a modem that was released two years ago, and it is usually priced accordingly. If you're a Spectrum customer in an area where the "standard" service is 200Mbps, want to ensure a bit of room to (potentially) upgrade to faster service in the future, need something that just works, or have enough devices connected that your old modem is getting stressed, this one is fine.
title: Stable and fast

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2020
review_content: I have taken three months to write this review because I was concerned with some of the reviews that I read before buying this product. I can say that with the three months that it took to test and stress this system with two gaming computers and multiple media devices going at the same time, it performed and has held up to what I have come to expect from Netgear products. Excellent. Mind you, I have this paired with a Netgear Night hawk router and the network consistently maintains an average output of 440-480 MBS which is 10-20% more then I am rated for through my current network provider. So if you are looking for a reliable gaming network, Netgear has the products that can be scaled to your desired set up and perform consistently. Happy gaming.
title: 3 month test and stress

author: N. Hyland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2019
review_content: As you read reviews here, they are for *all* the different Netgear modems. I am talking about the Nighthawk Cable Modem with Voice CM1150V. (I wish Amazon did not do this!)- Pricey. I got it on sale but, it is still at the top price level for a non wi-fi cable modem.- Forget about what seems to be the ethernet jacks on the back. The Amazon and even the Netgear descriptions are wrong. The extra ethernet jacks are “reserved” for future aggregation of ethernet. Which happens via a business level router. IOW: for an office or high traffic/large file use situation.Why Netgear did not offer customers the option to make those ports a switch router in the mean time, is bonkers. Sure, maybe it is not technically possible as it is now so, the engineers should have made it technically possible when they designed the dang thing! Alternatively, sell a version for home, but with actual ports for a typical home network.The information I could find as to if Comcast (across USA) could even meet the requirements of this device remains unclear.  Comcast is terrible at keeping its information house in order.- Many parts of the Netgear web site seemed to have been phoned in and are minimal or have errors too.- Netgear only has technical support centers overseas. As usual, they are awful. Techs can't speak English without making errors; can't understand American conversational English; and generally do not know the product. When I asked if I could connect to a US call center (simply to speed it up and have CLEAR information), they said no. Not possible. (In contrast, Amazon does this transfer if you ask, thankfully, saving its customers hours of long useless conversations to nowhere. When Amazon stops doing that, it will be the day I stop being a customer — since 1995!)- All above is pretty much a deal killer for me on this one. I am probably returning it but, finding a suitable replacement has been a challenge. I'd like a DOCIS 3.1 24x8 or higher with voice or a DOCSIS 3.0 24x8 with voice. Both for less than $150. But I have only been able to find a DOCSIS 3.0 16x8 with voice and, for a older modem, it is overpriced and not high enough bonding numbers. The only 3.1 models with voice are the CM1150V (got on sale) and a competing Motorola but, it would cost the same not on sale. Other than a better warranty, no advantage. Actually, that Moto might just be 3.0… so worse…I may have to stick with paying way more than I want to Fios… These regional cable monopolies and duopolies we all suffer through in the USA need to end!
title: CM1150V: more for business & for techies, not for regular home broadband users

author: Michael J. Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2018
review_content: In my previous review last summer, I stated that the -1AZNAS version of this didn't work if you have Comcast.  I had  spent two hours on the phone with Comcast support in WA state trying to get this to work.  The tech finally told me that the vanilla CM1000 is supported by Comcast but the -1AZNAS (which apparently is a special SKU for sale by Amazon) is NOT supported.
