When they try to provision it on the network, it fails because the SKU isn't a recognized one.  It apparently is identical to the CM1000 but has a different model number that Comcast won't support.I tried again yesterday, thinking that maybe Comcast had updated their list of supported devices to now cover this.  The tech I got at Comcast was surprisingly helpful and knowledgable, but had to go into some backend tool to add the -1AZNAS designation to the SKU to get it to work - but it does now work.  So if you have trouble with Comcast, ask them to do that.
title: UPDATE - Now Works With Comcast in Seattle Area

author: Anthony
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: The one start is for ordering through Amazon. My service provider is Xfinity, I checked their website for compatibility modems. The Netgear CM1150V was on the list. When I received the modem it looked as if it was repackaged but I ignored it.. Over the weekend I connected the modem and everything worked fine, 4 TV’s, telephone and internet. Three days later I shipped the Xfinity back their modem via UPS. They provide a label and absorb the shipping cost. The next weekend all my TV’s stopped working because they needed to be re-activated. Trying to activate the TV’s with the code myself didn’t work and was forced to call Xfinity and wait on the call for three hours for a representative came online. The rented device was still showing up on my account and that is why my tv’s stopped working. They seem to get them working until the next weekend all the TV’s went dead again. Again few hours on the phone and third level told me the modem I purchased from Amazon is still assigned to the owners account and they cannot help me unless the owner releases. I wasn’t going to wait until Amazon contacted the owner, I packed it back and send it back for full refund. I went to Best Buy and purchased ArrisT25 from Bestbuy and has been working since I connected.
title: Repackaged modem - Buyer beware

author: Ryan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2019
review_content: I wish I had been aware of the Puma6 chipset issue. I got this modem to use on Suddenlink in August 2019. It is now Oct 31st--sadly after the window to return. It was chugging along at 400MBs down and 40 up and after ISP tested the line, and I attached my PC to the LAN port, It was clear that the bottleneck was/is this modem. Meaning I have to buy a new modem and light money on fire.  Modems are simple and just have to be registered with the ISP and then "work"..This "Puma6" chipset issue from Intel is a killer. can go to dslreports.com to learn about it and run a similar test on your modem like in the picture. The dark speedtest is my grafana ---top is download, bottom is upload...Just went to heck.
title: Ugh

author: MotownRock
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2018
review_content: Bought this to replace the unit I was renting from Xfinity. Installation was on par with any other modem – connect the wires, quick setup, and activate with Xfinity. The problem was inconsistent, and at times, awful performance. When connected to a router that had been reliably connecting at 50 to 80 Mbps, with my old modem, this device often cut the signal to less than 10 Mbps.I’ve been happy with multiple Netgear routers in the past and realize that tech devices can be hit or miss when they are mass-produced. The real issue with this purchase was Netgear itself.I called the support line, and after holding for an agent, he had me reboot and quickly told me it was an ISP issue and to call Xfinity. Spoiler alert: The Netgear agent turned out to be wrong.After long but productive troubleshooting call with Xfinity, we ruled out any line or compatibility issues. Switching between the 2 modems pinned the quality issues on the Netgear device with packet loss of 14-20% (over 5-10% is significant).My next call with Netgear to get a warranty exchange was worse than the first. The rep provided inconsistent and very misleading information. My first questions were whether the replacement would be a new device and if I would have to pay shipping in either direction. The agent said that I would get a “working” replacement and that there was a “zero cost” exchange option. When pressed, she said the replacement would be refurbished that I had to pay for return shipping with “zero cost” option. If I wanted a refurbished unit, I could have bought one for less money instead of paying for new PLUS shipping. When I asked her to escalate the call, she said her manager was busy but would call me in “4 or 5 hours.” That would have been after 11pm so she promised that I would get a call the next day. That was 3 days ago and still no callback.My take is that Netgear support will say anything to clear their call queue and company doesn’t fully stand behind its products. I actually got better support from the cable company. Think about that.I wound up returning it to Amazon with zero hassle and paid a few bucks more for TP-Link modem with better specs. I’ve had good luck with a recently-purchased TP-Link router and am hoping for the same with their modem. As for Netgear, they’ve lost this customer and I encourage other potential customers to think carefully before buying Netgear based on their trust of the brand.
title: Slow. Poor Support. Weak Warranty

author: Paul Wagner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2018
review_content: I purchased the CM500 to replace my Motorola cable modem with Xfinity.I went through the setup procedure, including the Comcast activation. For whatever reason, it simply would never activate through Xfinity, nor could the support people get it working despite considerable time on the phone.I finally gave up and plugged my Surfboard back in, which worked perfectly fine.I cannot be certain as to whether this was an issue with the modem or an issue with Xfinity.I'll add that the Surfboard is built like a tank, though similar in size. The Netgear unit is lightweight, bordering on flimsy. Both are only DOCSIS 3.0, despite the Surfboard being years older.
title: Worthwhile if you lease your existing modem. That being said, returning it because I couldn't get it to work with Xfinity.

author: Fyreous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
review_content: Many of the reviews here (on the CM1000 model specifically) have commented about how the product description says that this modem has been newly-certified to work with Spectrum's network (as of Nov. 2018), but the box it arrives in specifically says that it's NOT certified to work with Spectrum. Hopefully, I can shed some light on that for you all. In short, the box is wrong.I just finished setting up the CM1000 on Spectrum's 400mbps-tier plan in the RDU area, and I can state definitively that it indeed does work with this tier of service! I had to call and have it manually-provisioned by their tier-2 tech support, but it was a quick process and they got it up and running in about 20 minutes for me.The reason I bought the CM1000 was for future-proofing purposes of having a DOCSIS 3.1-capable modem. I hope to upgrade to the Gig-tier service once Spectrum allows it in my area for customer-owned modems. As of right now in Jan 2019 though, they only allow Gig service on a modem that they provide you (the Technicolor 4400). That's okay though. For now, my 400mbps-tier is working just fine with this CM1000, and I don't have to deal with a modem lease from Spectrum this way. If they enable Gig-tier speeds for this modem at any point in the future, I will return to update this review accordingly.
title: Yes, the CM1000 works with Spectrum in the RDU area; but not the highest Gig-tier (yet)

author: Tim Hewitt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2019
review_content: I wasted an entire day after having X-Finity installed only to realize that either this unit was a dud, or it simply does not work with X-Finity. It would connect for a minute, then could not hold authentication. It created all kinds of network issues and even MAC spoofing provided no solution. I plugged in a different router the next day and all my problems went away, and everything worked as it should. I really did not feel like wasting any more time with Netgear trying to troubleshoot a defective product, so, I returned it. If you look at other reviews you will see I am not alone.
title: CM1000 Either a dud or no good for X-Finity

author: Michael Muller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2020
review_content: This one was a bit more work to do. After I received the product, I did what the box said. Connect and play. It wasn't that simple. After calling my ISP and connecting the modem, I ran into a problem where it showed that I was connected to the modem, but no internet going through to my modem. I called Netgear and they were able to walk me through a troubleshoot of my modem and realized that majority of the channels weren't closed. Netgear told me to call my ISP and asked them to help me close all the channels so that the internet can be connected to the modem. After 10-15 mins on the phone with my ISP I had internet. All my ISP did was actually re-program my modem so that internet can go through.
title: Suddenlink here

author: ScubaDive
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: To be clear, I paid the full, new item price for this modem.  When I received the modem, it came in the manufacture’s box with a label on the front – NOT in the normal Amazon smiley face box.  The manufactures box did not have the usual clear shrink wrap plastic on the outside.  I also noticed that the box was not sealed with tape as would normally be the case.  Needless to say, I was suspicious.When I opened the box, I was astounded to see that there was a paper inside.  It was the top half of the paper you print out when you print a return label on the Amazon site.  The part that says, All Items Must Be Sent by XXX XX XXXX date, and also says, Tell Us About Your Return Experience.  Someone had obviously returned this (supposedly new) item!  On further inspection, I noticed that the various cables were no longer tied with the wire ties as you would expect, and there was one tie still laying in the box.  AGAIN, THIS IS AN ITEM THAT CLEARLY STATES:  SHIPS FROM AND SOLD BY AMAZON.COM.I immediately called Amazon and they agreed to send me another modem immediately and paid for me to return the used item.  I have used Amazon pretty much since its inception and been a Prime Member shortly after they started the Prime program.  This is the first time I have ever received a used product when I ordered a new one.  Needless to say, I'm very disappointed.PS - the replacement modem came in the usual Amazon box and was sealed and packaged as normal for new items.  The modem was fairly easy to install and seems to work well thus far.
title: WARNING:  I received a USED modem - same as many others (according to their reviews)

author: Dawn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2019
review_content: I go through modems way quicker than I should. Not sure why but i was on the phone with the cables tech support who couldn't tell me whether or not the problem was my modem or their line (like always). They made me an appointment for 2 days from my call. In the meantime I googled "best modem" and got a link to a lightning deal on this one and managed to get it on a terrific sale with one day shipping. So the modem arrived before the technician did! I hooked it up, called the cable co to give them the MAC address to turn it on and my problem was not only gone but this thing has made my connection faster and everything connected to the internet more responsive than it was even before the old modem gave up! I cancelled the appointment for the technician to come out cause I don't one now!!
title: Great purchase!

author: J.W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2020
review_content: Netgear products don't deliver the speeds they advertise!I purchased Netgear's CM500 modem and the RC6080 router, to replace an old Netgear combo router/modem that was only giving me 70mbps wireless download speeds. I pay for 200 mbps and selected these two devices because both are advertised as supporting wireless download speeds greater than 200 mbps. The box of the AC1000 literally has written right on the front: "WiFi speeds up to 300+700Mbps." When I set up the new modem and router, I still only got 70mbps (wired connection was 260+). When I contacted Netgear for help, they told me that sorry the router box had "false advertising" (their words) and that really it could only do 100mbps max. They suggested I purchase a 250 dollar router instead.  Don't buy Netgear, the products have false advertising and the help was rude and unhelpful.
title: Netgear Products Don't Work!

author: Private User
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review_content: Install was easy and the device worked as one would expect for about 8 months.  After 8 months it started having multicast ranging errors and the connection to my ISP would only stay active for less than a minute.  Provider came out and checked the line and had full signal strength an top connection speeds, whereas the router connected to the modem was lucky to get 20mbps down and 0.5mpbs up.  Previously speeds had been over 200 down and 14 up.Lines and connections were inspected and tested and found to be in proper operating order.  ISP replaced the modem with one of their modems and the speeds were back to normal.Contacted Netgear support.  It was past the 90 day warranty but within the 1 year hardware support window.  Netgear said "not our modem's problem" and was willing to provide support for $130 for a year.  I politely declined as that was far too expensive and beyond the my needs, plus if everything outside of the modem tests fine, the reasonable deduction is that it is the modem that is faulty.
title: Worked well for 8 months, then died.  Netgear unwilling to support w/o more $$

author: KTDO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2020
review_content: To save you some of the hassles I experienced or might have experienced here are a few tips (from a total non-techie):1. Note that this doesn't include a router. I think it makes it cheaper, and if you have your own router already you wont have to worry about de-activating (activating?) "bridge mode".  I have an eero wifi router mesh system so didn't need this to have a router built in.2. This does accommodate voice connection. Many routers don't, including some of the Netgear options within this same product listing, so make sure you select one that has voice if you need it for your VOIP service.3. I have Comcast/Xfinity. It could have been an easy setup, but I missed one step. This cost me hours. To activate Comcast, once you have the modem plugged into power, the round cable thing connected, and the phone jack connected, you are supposed to connect your computer to the modem with an ethernet cable plugged into the TOP ethernet port in the modem. This is apparently the only one that works. Close all browsers then open a fresh one and you'll automatically get instructions from Comcast about how to activate. The modem reboots itself when activated and you see all the lights turn on and become solid. Here's where I screwed up. You need to take your computer's ethernet cable out of the modem and then plug your router's cable into that same port.  (I had plugged it into one of the other ports, which, again, don't work).  THEN, you have to re-boot it all: unplug your router from power (or however you shut it down), turn off the Netgear modem. Then turn each on again, in sequence. (However, I don't remember if it was modem first then router, or the other way around! Just try each). The Comcast instructions never mention that you need to remove your computer's ethernet, nor do they discuss re-booting. Those were the clinchers for me.4. This doesn't have a backup battery so when the power goes out, it goes out. With many modems, you can buy a separate little battery that will buy you some time. With this modem, you have to buy a separate "uninterrupted power supply," which is like a power strip that will operate for a period of time without power.
title: A few tips...

author: Yoshi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2019
review_content: My ISP is Xfinity by Comcast. It's Saturday, Feb 2, 2019. The issue I had was that I needed the ISP's information (Ip address, default gateway, etc) in order to get my Netgear modem to communicate with my Netgear Router. The Netgear router is model: WGR614 v9. I tried calling Xfinity to give me the information I needed first, but was told that because the router is customer owned, I would have to speak with Netgear. That they (Netgear) were the only one who has access to the IPv4 address. Comcast had access to only the IPv6 address and nothing else. So, I called Netgear's customer support and was able to speak with a representative after about an hour of waiting. I asked for the information I needed, but was told that only Comcast could provide the information I needed. As you can imagine, this back and forth went on for a long while. A more than five hour while. I was finally able to get both a Comcast and Netgear representative on the line and they sort of duked it out amongst themselves. Unfortunately, no solution came from that attempt. Ultimately, Netgear said that because my router was manufactured 1 year ago, it was considered obsolete and was no longer supported. They told me that the only possible solution they could think of was to buy a new router, that is of the same brand, otherwise they couldn't assist me. I will be posting a recording of the conversation in a bit and pasting the link on here as proof. The modem seemed to be functioning okay. I was able to connect to the internet through the Ethernet that was connected from the modem to my computer.
title: expect 5 hour wait times from netgear

author: Julie D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2018
review_content: This modem quit working in less than two months. If you call their service center during business hours (they're open 24/7) be prepared to wait a very long time. The first time I called I waited one hour, the second was forty five minutes. If your modem breaks and it's still under their one year warranty, you'll need to mail it in at your expense and be without internet. I went to Xfinity and waited in line an hour to get their modem. This is the second NETGEAR cable modem I've purchased and the first one lasted over two months, Amazon refunded my money that time.
title: Quit Working

author: Timezone
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2020
review_content: The Modem was very easy to setup and Comcast was even easier.  In advance and before the setup I supplied Comcast with the two Mac addresses.  The Xfinity.com/Activate did not work on my PC.  I had the PC direct connected to the Modem.  I know why it didn't work and will explain in a bit.  I went to the Xfinity site on my phone. It has a connection to the mobile carrier.  Xfinity web page knew I had a device to provision and in seconds it was provisioned.  Except nothing worked.I now have a better appreciation of link aggregation.  I am very much aware this is a modem and NOT a modem/router.  Without link aggregation only one device either a PC or Router can be connected to the modem.  Otherwise it would be a modem/router.  I get that but I still bought this assuming I could add multiple devices to the Modem.  Which explains the initial problem I had getting my PC to work.  The modem didn't like having all the ethernet ports connected to various devices. I called Netgear and got it up and running by removing all the ports except for the PC and we reset the Modem.  Next I removed the PC and connected a four year old Orbi RBR50.  It didn't work.  I was still on the phone with Netgear and was able to get this working with some assistance. Changes to the Orbi setup fixed the connectivity issue.  I also power cycled the modem.  My Wifi is definitely faster with this modem but I can't prove it. I didn't run a speed test before changing Modems.  Wifi speeds Download = 341 Mbps  Upload = 12.1Overall I am happy with this purchase.  It is a future proof purchase because I won't come close to the allowed speeds on this modem.Orbi RBR50  - No idea or guarantee this fixes all Router Manufacture or Models connectivity to the CM1150V1. Internet IP Address  -  Get Dynamically from ISP2. Set Router Mac address  -  Use Computer Mac address3. Domain Name Server (DNS) Address  -  Get Automatically from ISP*******UPDATE*******About a week after the purchase the Modem died.  All four ethernet lights were on even when I removed the router to it.  The power light (red) and globe came on for a second and then shut off.  Testing with Netgear proved it was dead.  Amazon could not do an exchange.  I got a refund.  Despite my better judgement I bought it again but this time from BB.  This product shipped from Amazon would have taken almost a week.  I needed a working Modem.  Happy with the refund from Amazon but when it comes to critical infrastructure items I wished Amazon had a better exchange policy.The Comcast phone and internet worked right away.  Around the same time the service dropped.  Calling Comcast they had both my old and new modem on file and the Netgear was not active.  Not sure why it worked for a week.  I recommend not activating the modem using the online xfinity/activation process.  Call Comcast to provision the equipment as others have suggested.***To Netgear - it may be obvious to the network engineers of the world that these  are not regular ethernet ports.  The package states they are ethernet ports.  Technically correct but with a special function.  By not being clear on the packaging you are being deceptive. Even the description lends some doubt. "4 Gigabit Ethernet ports (allow 2 LAN aggregation to double wired speeds)"  What are the other 2 ethernet ports doing?
title: CM1150V - Excellent Modem with Voice (but beware)

author: LinkedInSecrets - Author of 4 LinkedIn Books
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: This is the first time I have bought an electronic technology item and missed one important item that was missing from the product description. That feature is "Router". This cable-modem is not a router, so it does not provide routing or DHCP services. I knew it did not have WiFi, which for me was a bonus.I did test the device and I was able to get a connection to the internet using my single IP address assigned by the ISP. I could not get higher download speeds than 200 mps. I used speedtest dot net to connect to a local server as part of the test.This cable modem will only work in environments where you lease more than 1 IP address, or when you have a wifi | router connected to each of the 4 ports, or just the 1.It did have one other feature that I was not able to test - channel bonding. That's a great option, but I doubt residential setups will use it. Channel bonding on this cable modem works on ports 1 and 2. You configure it via the admin ip address web interface. This option has to be supported by your ISP as well.I am interested in this Cable Wifi Router Modem:   NETGEAR Nighthawk Cable Modem WiFi Router Combo (C7800) - Compatible with Cable Providers Including Xfinity by Comcast, Cox, Spectrum | Cable Plans Up to 2 Gigabits | AC3200 WiFi Speed | DOCSIS 3.1          . I had to reach out to Amazon to find this product.My Lesson Learned: look for the words "Wifi & Router" + cable modem. This cable modem has been returned to Amazon.Note: Due to the virus situation since March 2020, the supply and demand of this product is impacted.
title: Works, but not in my Home Office Setup

author: Cary in Va.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2020
review_content: I fought this thing for 4 weeks, losing signal and having to Hard Power 0ff . Probably every 3 days. Losing signal meant my 5 Ring Devices would cease to perform.  After pulling out my last Hair , I called the Tech Line.  Where the Rep will be speaking with a thick accent , and my Va. accent was not helping either. So, I found out even though I had not had the Router longer than a month , it had 2 Firmware Updates that were not installed.  Mind you the NetGear App you download on your Smart Phone has an Update Check to do for you.  This does not function. It will say NO UPDATES at this time available.  Even though I was 2 firmware updates behind. It looks like NetGear would have sent me a current firmware on this Router . No worries though, if you're up to 2 hrs. of Tech Assistance with someone in Baliwood . You will have to use your Lap Top, Desk Top , connected ( hard wired) with an Ethernet Cable directly to your Router, and start browsing for your Router IP address in 1 window and then open another window to go to your Netgear acct and download the current Firmware to your Desktop , Documents, etc. and go to the other window where you have your Advanced Tab and try try try to get it to update, I had given up and finally Rebooted the system and when it came back up it had the current firmware downloaded. Thank you Jesus . This appears  that it has corrected the Hard Power off every 3 days, or so.  So it was the out of date firmware causing the frustration. BUT they need to address why the simple tab to check for downloads on the iPhone app says it's current when it is not . That's why that option is included  within the Netgear Nighthawk  app.
title: WIFI u stress me out Router ?

author: N. Head
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: To preface - I'm an advanced user - have 20+ years computer and networking experience. I started having intermittent internet issues a few months ago, after owning this modem for almost a year. The modem would just stop talking to my internet provider, until I rebooted it. The status page said everything is OK. I went through many troubleshooting steps - replacing all my coaxial lines and testing for noise (no problems) - replacing my ethernet cables - moving the modem to where it has more airflow/cooling - etc - and still the problem persisted. I must conclude that the modem has some hardware or software defect.Looking at getting it replaced, Netgear does offer RMA over the phone - however their "tech support" is only 90 days from purchasing the device - otherwise they expect you to buy a support contract with them - which is completely insane for a $200+ device. I will not be recommending Netgear products any longer. And I will have to try and sell this as-is to recoup the losses. I won't ever get my lost time back, though.Update: I contacted their support to get this device RMA’d and the rep was polite but basically said since my device turns on, it’s not a hardware issue- and that since I’ve owned it longer than 90 days I’d have to buy a support contract through them to troubleshoot. Yeah— no. I cannot recommend NETGEAR to anyone as a brand anymore.
title: Started misbehaving after almost a year.. tech support being 90 days is silly

author: Bruce Perens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: I got this CM1200 to replace an Arris SB8200 that I had for two years or so. The Netgear CM1200, so far, has not dropped the connection since I got it, and is reporting significantly fewer errors than the Arris SB8200 did on the same connection.My home is far from the cable company head-end, and their system commands our modem to transmit with high upstream power so that our signal will reach them. The SB8200 reboots when it is commanded to about 40 dBmv per upstream channel, dropping the connection. This is noted in the log as "Dynamic Range Window Violation". The Netgear CM1200 is capable of a higher transmitter power, and happily exceeds the 40 dBmv that was the show-stopper for the Arris. Both modems had "extended upstream power" enabled. The CM1200 is running 35 dBmv on 4 upstream channels and 39.3 on the fifth, and I've seen it commanded to 41.5 dBmv so far without a need to reboot. Both modems are probably using the Broadcom BCM3390 chipset, the log entries of both modems look similar so the firmware is probably related.Also, the Netgear CM1200 has an error log, which persists across a power-clear, while the Arris SB8200 _used_ to have an error log, and no longer does. It got removed with a firmware update pushed by Comcast Business during the past year. Was it removed because more memory was needed for another purpose, or because that log is just too incriminating about poor cable performance? Nobody's going to tell me.The Netgear CM1200 has four ethernet ports, all usable, while the Arris SB8200 had two ports, and the second was only usable with port-bonding turned on (which means both would be connected to the same device). The Netgear CM1200 can bond two ports while the other two remain gigabit ports, or all 4 can be used as gigabit ports.. Having 4 usable ports means I can take an ethernet switch out of my network setup, and have one less thing to fail.The modem contains Open Source software, and Netgear properly and prominently displays the GPL license. They don't however, have the source code on their Open Source site (use Google) at this writing. The source code for the next older modem is present, and is probably similar.
title: Worked better than Arris SB8200

author: Adam B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2018
review_content: I upgraded my modem from an older DOCSIS 3.0 modem, which maxed out at ~26Mb/s and instantly went to ~48MB/s speed. I then upgraded my internet service with my ISP and basically maxed out the bandwidth based on what was available in my area (~220MB/s).For reference, my service is with Comcast Xfinity, and the physical change in the modem was very easy, as it was a straight drop-in replacement for me.  The only annoyance was having to actually talk to a Comcast representative on the phone to have them switch out the MAC address settings in their system for my connection, otherwise the service wasn't authorized. Both the website activation page (which was available after hookup) and the automated phone service menu didn't offer me a way to perform the switch-out automatically, so be ready to call them up and read over the MAC address to get things up and running.The resulting speed upgrades led to Netflix and Amazon Prime Video running better, with higher resolution, when having multiple sessions, and some services like PlayStation NOW ("streaming" online games for older PS systems) going from totally unusable to working perfectly. Overall, this was a very worthwhile purchase that I am very glad that I made.
title: As fast as advertised

author: Bill Hickman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
review_content: It says 4 1g Lan ports. This is false. Only one Lan port works at a time. I just talked to customer service. Only one works, but they are there to "future proof it." meaning, they don't work but maybe in the future. A bit of false advertisement. Get a decent modem and save some money. This only provides 1 port... Just like every other modem.
title: False advertisement.

author: Vivek Raman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2017
review_content: We got the NetGear as part of the Amazon Black Friday Deal. The first unit that we got was defective, however thanks to the excellent support by Amazon, this got replaced.On receiving the updated equipment, followed the setup instructions on the pack. It took exactly 10 minutes to set this up. Please note that they recommend plugin an Ethernet for setup, and if you are on a mac (like I am), you will need an adaptor (I had one - you can get one here:https://www.amazon.com/UGREEN-Ethernet-Adapter-Nintendo-Chromebook/dp/B00MYT481C)After the setup, my WIFI speeds seems to be more stable and much much faster. Hitting 100 MBPS over air.
title: Fast & Works

author: Chris K
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: Couldn't have been easier to install. Connected to a new 100Mb Comcast circuit and that was it. Been running solid for four months without a hiccup. Saves me a huge monthly modem rental, and lets me run the firewall of my choice without having the ISP sitting in the way.
title: Easy and stable

author: Kamikaze
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2020
review_content: I replaced my old Arris SB6190 modem with the Netgear CM1000. As you can see in the picture it's the CM1000v2 modem. The version Spectrum requires. Setup took Spectrum all but sixty seconds and I was online with no problems. Since the CM1000 doesn't have Intel's Puma chipset it doesn't suffer from overloading. The modems listed below all have the Intel Puma Chipset and should be avoided. There's currently a class action lawsuit going on concerning it. My previous modem was plagued by codeword errors, but now I have none.ARRIS CM3200ARRIS DG1660ARRIS DG1670ARRIS DG2460ARRIS DG2470ARRIS DG3260ARRIS DG3270ARRIS DG3450ARRIS SBG10ARRIS SB6190ARRIS SBG6950AC2ARRIS SBG7400AC2ARRIS SBG7580ACARRIS SBG7600AC2ARRIS SBG8300ARRIS SBV2402ARRIS SBV3202ARRIS SVG2482ACARRIS T25ARRIS TG1652ARRIS TG1662ARRIS TG1672ARRIS TG1682ARRIS TG2472ARRIS TG3452ARRIS TM1602ARRIS TM3402ASUS CM-32Hitron CDA3Hitron CDA3-35Hitron CGN3Hitron CGNM-2250Hitron (CGNM) CGNM-2252Hitron CGNVM-2559Hitron CGNM-3550Hitron CGNM-3552Hitron CGNVM-3580Hitron CGNVM-3582Hitron CGNVM-3589Hitron CODA-45Hitron CODA-4502Hitron CODA-4580Hitron CODA-4582Hitron CODA-4589Hitron CODA-46Hitron CODA-4602Hitron CODA-4680Hitron CODA-4682Hitron CODA-4689Hitron CODA-47Hitron CODA-4702Hitron CODA-4780Hitron CODA-4782Hitron CODA-4789Linksys CG6350Linksys CG7500Linksys CM3016Linksys CM3024NETGEAR C6300-100NASNETGEAR C6300v2NETGEAR C6300BDNETGEAR CBK40NETGEAR CBR40NETGEAR CM700
title: Works with Spectrum

author: stevendavid2000
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2017
review_content: So I've had this modem for a few weeks. I used to have a Motorola Surfboard 6141 I believe (going off memory). That modem at times would randomly drop speeds down to 1mb/s maximum for no reason, then throttle back up. I tried to research this and found out it might have been related to the Time Warner Maxx internet package I have (I'm grandfathered into a package that currently doesn't exist). No idea how or why that would matter but it seems to be the reason why my old Surfboard was having problems.So a deal hit and I dropped cash for this modem in hopes I could solve this problem fairly cheaply and so far its working. I haven't noticed any lag, no strange behavior like dropping to 1mb/s speeds, its been consistent and constant fast speeds, even above the stated speeds I should receive. The unit is well ventilated so the concern of heating up is not an issue. It's barely warm to the touch. I think as others have stated, if you put this in a confined space, for example an entertainment center with a glass door, then it'll heat up more than likely because there's no internal fan. But if you provide adequate air circulation then it'll function perfectly from my point of view.Also I wasn't able to successfully hook up the unit and remotely update to Time Warner that I am switching modems (Mac address) so I had to call them. The tech was able to get me going and took about 10 mins.All in all its so far a great intermediate modem.
title: Best mid-range value modem

author: Ryan M Schultz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: I bought this modem to replace my Arris Surfboard modem that had aged and became a bit faulty (but still better than a Netgear modem apparently). I figured I would try something new, and I regret that.Let's start with install: -5 out of 5 stars.It took me nearly 5 hours to even get this modem to give me internet access. I followed directions as explained in the manual for Xfinity install. I'm less than impressed with the install, since I have never spent more than 30 minutes installing any modem I have owned, before or after this one, to connect to the internet.*The Arris Surfboard SBG8300 that I replaced this time-vampire with took me 15 minutes to setup and have internet access.Connection Stability: 2 out of 5 stars.I reset this router every single day hoping to correct connectivity issues. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't. I tried wired and (with a extra purchase of a router) wifi to see if there was a difference, there was not. As an avid gamer, I strongly suggest avoiding this modem unless you thoroughly enjoy being frustrated during game play.*I have had zero issues with the replacement modem (Arris Surfboard SBG8300) for connections.User Controls: 0 out of 5 stars.I feel that the marketing strategy on this modem was that it should be so amazing that it doesn't need you to have options or parameters via the modem ip address portal, which would be fair, if that was actually true.Maybe I'm a modem snob in my expectations on this one, but this modem offers 0 user control. Don't expect any.*Any modems I have owned in the past, not just Arris brand, have had user control in the ip portal. This was a head-scratching product development choice, in my opinion.Price to Value: 0 out of 5 stars.This modem is expensive (borderline robbery) considering its just a modem, and not router/wifi combo. You wanted wifi too? Be prepared to fork out even more money pairing a router with this thing.*Arris surfboard SBG8300 wasn't any better in price, but does act as a router/wifi combo, and in my experience has earned its price through being everything that this modem is not.Did it seem like I was advertising Arris? Yes? Good. Save yourself a headache and buy anything else, but if i had to suggest something, it would be the Arris Surfboard SBG8300.
title: Great Site Reviews, Less Than Stellar Product

author: TB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: Returning this product within the 'return window' resulted in numerous emails where they expressed desire to charge me an undisclosed amount of money due to a piece of paper (User Guide) and a basic ethernet cable.  They would not help me with a description of the ethernet cable nor the UG which I wrote on during setup.  They demonstrated repetitive responses without any clarification that they will not refund the full amount as a result of these items not included in the box. When it became clear they were more intent on taking my money rather than help come to a solution, they would not discuss how much money was going to be held back.  Only after the transaction was completed did I find out that these two items cost me $73 !!!!!  The modem, charger and packing was in perfect condition.  Yet somehow they worm their way to deducting $73 for these basic items which at most would be $5.  Neutron USA is the seller of this product which I strongly recommend looking elsewhere when researching this Cable Modem from Netgear.  Or run the risk of loosing a lot of money per their unreasonable discretion.
title: Tech Support leaves a lot to desire

author: Miklos P. Kadar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review_content: I bought this cable modem to replace an older model Motorola modem that could not support my upgraded Internet service. I only needed to unbox it, connect to the incoming line and my wired/wireless router, verify functionality with the Comcast service lady on the other end of the phone line and I was in business at full 100Mb/sec.I am running with this modem for over a month and had zero issues with it. I would recommend to set it up in an environment where it is not boxed in so the air can circulate through it for cooling.If you are running your service at the speed I am at, this modem will work for you just fine.
title: This cable modem works just fine

author: Harrison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: Junk.  Freezes constantly. After a power outage; forget it, it takes HOURS to come back or you have to reset, reinstall, etc.  NETGEAR Customer Service is a COMPLETE joke; you get 90 days support from the date of purchase... this was gifted and did not get hooked up until two months later.... so wegot 30 days... after that you have to pay neck here to help you out. I was thinking that Netgear I have been a long-standing name and therefore it would’ve been good and supportive. I was wrong, it’s an old dinosaur. Do yourself a favor and purchase another brand.
title: Freezes constantly. Support is a joke.

author: Christopher Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2018
review_content: I'm very pleased with this modem.  Our nine year old modem Motorola SB6120 had become obsolete and wasn't allowing us to experience the full 250 Mbps Comcast plan we were paying for.  Enter the NETGEAR CM1000 modem.  This modem gives us a little more speed than the plan we're on.  We consistently get 253 Mbps download and 12 Mbps upload.  Besides that, it's a DOCIS 3.1 modem, so we're good to go if we ever wish to increase our Internet plan.
title: Doubled my speed and future proof

author: John R. Kathrein
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2019
review_content: Getting straight to the point: the Netgear CM1000 is a piece of junk. I purchase my first unit in mid 2018. Within a month, it dropped the Comcast Internet signal and I had to reboot it. The problem accelerated until it would not reboot; the bottom red light on. By then, the warrantee had expired. Along the way, I purchase the same modem as a backup. When the first one died, I installed the second one.  Within 6 weeks the dropped connection began and it died soon after. Makes me wonder if Comcast has a kill signal that burns out third party modems! Needing a reliable internet connection, I finally gave in and had a Comcast modem installed. I hate paying the monthly fee! Bottom line: DO NOT BUY THIS MODEM!
title: Installed 2 Units. Both failed quickly. Total Junk!

author: kgs
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2018
review_content: I’m in the process of replacing and discarding this modem after less than five months of use. I purchased it new. It worked fine for the first two months.  In the third month, it started dropping the connection (Spectrum 300 MB/s) about once a week.  By the fourth month, the connection was dropping daily. Now, in the fifth month, it drops several times per day.I’ve been a TWC/Spectrum internet customer for over 15 years at this location and have never had connectivity issues like this.  It’s definitely this Netgear modem. The modem log consists primarily of two types of failure events: “Sync Timing Synchronization failure” and “No Maintenance Broadcasts for Ranging opportunities received.“
title: Discarding this modem after less than 5 months of use

author: Wayne Jacks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: Worked great for the first 8 months, then it started failing.I assumed it was our service provider, but after days of back and forth (during a work from home pandemic, not ideal) turns out it’s this little chap.Netgear charge for support calls, but the overseas help desk were kind enough to waive the first help call.Apparently it was a fault somewhere in the IP management on the device.They fixed it, and the very next day it went down again. I followed the steps I saw the guy go through remotely, but I was down for another 2 hours.The next 4 days were a carbon copy repeat of the issue, however if I called in to Netgear to have them fix or replace the hardware which was under warrantee, I would be charged for every call (even to set up the return).The 4th day I just had enough. It had cost me more in lost productivity than buying another modem.I pulled the plug and bought a new one (NOT Netgear!).WHEN IT DID WORK....It was fine. Supposedly fast modem. No built in WiFi or extra Ethernet ports. Very basic for what it costs. Would be better if, at this price point, it had WiFi or Ethernet ports/switch built in
title: Failed after 8 months

author: Chris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: Purchased in November of 2018. I was using this modem with Spectrum's 400mbps tier service for the last 10 months, and previously on XFinity at 300mbps for the ~12 months prior to that. Within the last week (August 2020) it started freaking out and resetting every couple minutes. It would go offline indefinitely where it wouldn't even try to pull a downstream signal (unless I reset it). It was not a Spectrum issue, as my neighbor's internet remained online throughout the issues with zero interruption (also Spectrum).I tried everything: software reset through the web portal, hard reset from the unit, etc. Nothing fixed it. It continued to just be terrible and "spazzing out". It's frustrating to have something work and then become a brick. Replaced with an Arris SB6192 (dropped down to Docsis3.0) and am getting a perfect 460mpbs down on my 400mbps plan.Note: I also used this with an XR500 and XR700 router and the routers did NOT perform well. Regardless of DumaOS settings, I couldn't pull more than 50mbps down to any device (even with QOS off or QOS on and at 100 for a single device - would still cap it at 50). I switched to the Nighthawk MK62 and am pulling 300-460mpbs ON WIFI throughout the house now.
title: Broke within 2 years. Do not recommend.

author: T. Pultz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2019
review_content: I needed to upgrade my cable modem w/voice to take advantage of my "gig speed" connection.  I chose the new Netgear CM1150V since it was on the Xfinity approved list, and was really the only option for a DOCSIS 3.1 modem w/voice.  As you can see from the images I installed the CM1150V in my Structured Media Center (SMC).  I removed the base with a Torx-8 screwdriver and attached the unit to mounting brackets with Velcro.Activation couldn't have been easier.  I connected my laptop directly to the modem, turned on the unit (it has a convenient On/Off switch), and within a short time a browser window popped up and I was connected to the Xfinity service.  I stepped through the quick account verification steps and literally in about 10 minutes everything, including phone, were active and running fine.As installed in my SMC this modem seems to runs pretty cool... I can barely feel any warmth at the top of the unit.  My main complaint is the very dim status lights, which can only been seen in the dark.  I guess if the modem was installed in a visible location very bright status lights would be annoying, but I still think they could be more prominent.Download/upload speeds are good, but not nearly close to my advertised gig speed.  I'm consistently getting about 300 Mbps down and 40 Mbps up.  The cable infrastructure in our circa 1984 neighborhood probably needs an upgrade.Overall I'm very satisfied as this DOCSIS 3.1 unit should be "future proof" for quite some time and the moderate size allowed me to install it directly in my SMC in place of the old, obsolete Arris.
title: CM1150V Super Easy Installation

author: Leroy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: For the money I paid, I thought  it would be lightning fast! It works, but lags a lot!! Well I call my local Internet provider for them to take a look. They say their part up-to modem is perfectly fine but the modem is not performing? I called Net gear and naturally I get somebody from the other side of the world that I can’t understand.  He keeps putting me on hold as if he were to ask somebody else the question I asked him because he doesn’t understand the questions I’m asking him. Finally I give him the serial number and model number of this unit and says I have to send him proof of purchase via email. I called the next day and they have blocked my phone number out because they say this item was purchased previously and no longer has any warranty. Also the modem comes with some security system and boy it is so annoying. I tried to turn it off every which way and it will not let you turn it off. Naturally Returning this item. Best to buy your equipment from Best Buy with a warranty so it can be returned for a new item. Now Amozon won't even exchange it.
title: Lesson learned

author: Jay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: Just unwrapped my CM1200. I unplugged my old modem; disconnected my WiFi router and then connected and powered up the new modem. I had to call xfinity and have them add the MAC address and send the reboot signals because the web activation didn’t work for me but after that, I reconnected my WiFi router and everything worked as expected.I wasn’t expecting much because my 9 year old Cisco DCP3008 is an 8x4 DOCSIS 3.0 router and rated higher than my 150mbps plan but I also wasn’t getting 150 over WiFi. To my surprise, on the 5G WiFi band, I went from 127mbps to 175mbps using the same test. My test wasn’t super scientific but directionally there was big jump in overall bandwidth and I credit this to the new hardware and the 32x8 stream support. It’s not very noticeable since most devices don’t use that much bandwidth for browsing and basic streaming... but I’m confident in the additional bandwidth and once everyone is connected and we have 4 people streaming the occasional slowness and re-buffering will improve. Overall, very happy on day one.
title: Measurable difference!

author: C. Watson III
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2019
review_content: I purchased this modem 6 months ago (yes I waited to write this review) only because Cox said customers needed to upgrade to a 3.0 or better docsis.  I was using a motorola 2.0 surboard which has NEVER given me one problem (I have a NETGEAR R7000 router). I figured since I was using NETGEAR products they'd all work seamlessly together. Wrong!  I could tell immediately that this thing didn't play nice dropping or changing connections but I've stuck with it trying and hoping it would come around but after months of unplugging and resetting I've come to the conclusion that it's just not good.  I contacted customer support and like several reviewers on here have said, its a joke.  They wanted me to go online first to create a case then contact them on the phone!  What?!  I'm going to go back to a cheaper Motorola product and see if that doesn't do the trick once again.
title: Can't recommend Netgear modems

author: secdroid
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
review_content: Verified that it was approved by Comcast before ordering.  Would not connect to xfinity.com/activate so I activated by phone.  After activation, it would not connect to Xfinity speed test site or the Internet.  Comcast was surprisingly helpful in trying to diagnose issue but ultimately concluded that all diagnostics showed that it was activated and provisioned properly.  Modem was the problem.  Said I should consult Netgear.The Netgear Genie control panel showed all was working properly.  (Xfinity gateway works flawlessly on this line.)Tried Xfinity community support forums.  Helpful, but no joy.  Googled Netgear knowledgebase and other sites.  No help.  Spent over one hour on chat with Netgear support.  Their only suggestion was to reset it, which had been done at least six times before.  No suggestions to how to diagnose.  No offer to repair or replace.Asked Amazon for return authorization, which was immediately granted.
title: Would not connect to Comcast

author: Laff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2019
review_content: Bought it to use Xfinity Gig - Started out fine, then had to reset as it dropped signal, finally after ethernet problems - did a modem factorty reset and it locked up the modem and Xfinity could not get it back online or working. .  Less than two months.  Horrible product - save your money - DO NOT BUY
title: Died in less than two months - Stay away

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2020
review_content: CM1200, this is a $200 product. It did not last a year, bought it Nov 2019, it is now Aug/Sept 2020. I had my ISP come out twice to do testing and change connectors, but in the end it was a bum modem. Intermittent drops for 3 weeks before it was solved by switching to my old SB6183.I’m glad it broke within the warranty window but the RMA process was awful. You submit your case, get a case number and you have to call in within 48 hours. Support will try to get you to buy support since your 90 day “complimentary support” is over, do not be a push over here, tell them their product is not working and still under warranty and you’d like to start the RMA process, tell them you’ve contacted your ISP and everything is good on their end. You will hopefully then get transferred to their technical support which you’ll have to say the same things and they will have look in the modem settings to try and verify, if all is good they will email you RMA details. This process took about 90 minutes, more than half that time I was on hold.Good luck trying to get your Netgear warranty, be adamant if you know it’s their product. Really unfortunate for this product, but I’ve had good experiences with a Netgear modem/router at another location for 6 years now so but this has been a sour experience. Get a better product from a company that will stand behind their product.
title: Did not last a year, RMA process is awful

author: MO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
review_content: There is no reason to have the four ethernet ports on the back. It wouldn't even work when I set it up for port aggregation by using two ethernet ports to a Nighthawk X6S. This thing is junk. It provides a signal fine but you still need to buy a wifi router. No reason for the extra ethernet ports, its not a switch or router and won't create a redundant signal for port aggregation. It's a bait and switch tactic. Calls to Netgear customer service were pretty worthless too, they are completely inept. I should have gone with an Arris, the one I replaced never had problems.
title: This has four ethernet ports, only one works. Port aggregation does not work.

author: Daniel Huang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
review_content: DO NOT BUY!!!!! I've been doing network hardware support for many years and this modem have been giving me a lot of problems.  As many users have reported, after 3 months you may start seeing problems, but you won't get any help because you're don't have phone support anymore.  If you know as a fact that the hardware has problems and you need a new modem they won't send you a new one until you pay money for phone tech support and tech support verifies that you need a new modem.  That's called a scam.  The person on the phone that was supposed to help me kept trying to sell me the extra phone support plan and  kept telling me LIES.  I know they were lies, because it contradicted the netgear website.  He won't even tell me the price of extra phone support.  I need to know how much something costs before I make a decision to buy it.  He kept asking me stupid question about if the "wifi light" was on...THERE is no wifi, it's a modem...he clearly doesn't know anything.  He said things like I can see that there's nothing wrong with your "router" it has be to be firmware problem...so you need the experts to diagnose the problems.  He doesn't know anything about my modem (not router), because... IT WASN'T EVEN ON, he has no access to it, STOP LYING!  I have hardware warranty, I know the hardware has problems...send me new hardware, I don't need to pay your hacks  to confirm that hardware has problems before I you send me new hardware.  There's something really suspect when the phone warranty is 3 months and the hardware suddenly has problems a little after 3 months and many other people say the same thing.  Buy an Arrius, never had a problem it, I decided to give netgear a try, BAD CHOICE!!!
title: WILL NOT LAST

author: Jasmine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
review_content: I purchased this product as a cheap modem for Xfinity internet 150mb/s plan.  The product came neatly packaged, and the instructions provided made set up simple. For the first month I had no issues. However, I started having connectivity issues soon after where the signal would drop every couple of days and the modem would take up to admit it to reset itself.  Eventually, this became a daily occurrence with multiple episodes throughout the day. The modem eventually died within 14 months.  I eventually decided against another Netgear modem due to this issue. So if you want to waste your money definitely purchase this item.
title: Waste of time and money

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: This seems to be an otherwise great product but the advertising is false and misleading.  It is a modem only and therefore only one of the Ethernet port actually works for ordinary uses.  Here are two totally misleading statements in the Amazon listing for this product:1. "4 x 1G Ethernet ports" - perhaps in theory they are Ethernet ports, but by design only one works.  If you want wifi and to plug your computer in via Ethernet, then you will need to buy a router to add to this setup.2. "• VERSATILE CONNECTIONS: 4 Gigabit Ethernet ports give you fast wired connections to your computer, separate WiFi router, printer, game box, and other devices."  For the same reason, this is totally, blatantly false.  There is only 1 Ethernet port that works for such purposes so to connect all of those devices you need to buy a router and plug that in and use the router to connect all of those devices.  No router is included with this purchase.
title: Totally misleading product description - you need a router too because ports 2-4 do not work

author: David Lavalley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2020
review_content: After 4 months of use this slows down the internet until I replug it and plug it back in.  This has to be done several times a day.  As of the last 2 weeks it just stops working for a little while.  It is not a cable issue, Comcast came ran a new wire to the house and connected the modem directly to that wire.  The issue still continues.  I called Net gear and for technical support they want to charge me  $130.00 for their techincal support  since it has been over 3 months since I bought it.  I also contacted Amazon and they worked hard to try to find a way for me to return it  but Netgear won't do a return after 30 days.  Also when you go to Netgears website if you don't want to pay the fee for support they tell you to try the community help.  When I looked up this issue with this particular problem many people are saying the same thing but there is no solution except to unplug and replug constantly.  This is a big bother to do that and then wait for the router to come back and then everything to reconnect.  My ADVICE STAY AWAY FROM NETGEAR.
title: STAY FAR AWAY FROM THIS AND ANY OTHER NETGEAR PRODUCT YOU WILL PAY MORE MONEY IN THE END

author: Kyle C Sampson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: First and foremost - this is a modem not a router. In other words it doesn't put out a WiFi signal. So if you need a box that is the modem (that gets you internet) and puts out WiFi signal for your wireless devices, this is not for you. This if for people who have or will get a router.That being said I am always amazed that many people don't know the speed that their current modem can handle. This model can go up to 1000 mbs downstream. We have paid for 300 mbs down from Xfinity for the last year. Our previous modem couldn't go that fast so we upgraded to this model. And we LOVE it! Now we are constantly getting about 280-350 mbs down.Before you buy this - check to see what you are paying for from your service provider and then see if you need this much speed. Or if you think you may increase in the near future.
title: So FAST! (this is not a router, just a modem)

author: Pensive Pundit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
review_content: I bought this cable modem after some study and evaluation of popular cable modems for sale.  I decided to buy it because I don't like the preset configuration of the Spectrum cable modem that comes with the Spectrum subscription.  I prefer one that is not pre-configured and I'm glad I bought my own cable modem now that I have it.I went to the Spectrum website to find pre-approved modem models that are compatible with Spectrum equipment (you can do this with any cable company).  I found that there are a lot of modems that are compatible, and I selected one based on the speed of my account and the price.  I run about 300 MB/s speed, so I selected the Netgear Cable Modem model CM700 because it's rated for at least 400 MB/s and the price was very reasonable when compared to the competition.I was pleased with the CM700 right out of the box.  It's much smaller than most other cable modems, and like most, it's mindlessly easy to hook up.  It has a power plug that goes to a 110 volt AC outlet, a cable plug that goes to the cable outlet on the wall, and an ethernet plug that can plug into a PC, or a router/wireless router, or even into a network switch (gigabit switch).Once I took the CM700 out of the box, I looked at the quick-start guide, and I had the CM700 set up and running in less than a minute.  I tested it, and it gives great speed too.  The CM700 plugs into my wireless router (the uplink plug). It feeds the wireless router and a PC that is wired directly to one of the wireless router ethernet output plugs.  The wireless speed I get from this set up is excellent, and the direct-connect speeds I get exceed my expectations.  Look at the pictures, and you'll see from the quick-start guide how easy the CM700 sets up.The only criticism I have of the CM700 is that it seems to run warm, but then again, it has no malfunctions whatsoever.  Also, I'm guessing that it has a great internal heat-sink, and I see that it has lots of holes for air ventilation, so that keeps it within the operating temperature range.Overall, I rate the CM700 a 5 star unit, based on both performance and price.
title: This Cable Modem is a Winner

author: Anil M. Dubey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2018
review_content: I just got the the NETGEAR DOCSIS 3.1 CM1000 modem yesterday and activated it on the XFINITY/COMCAST by calling the customer service. What a difference. First, my SPEEDTEST results have jumped 6-7 times for UPLOAD and at least 4-5 times for download. I had ARIS TG862G earlier and it was working well for 115-120 Mbps download and 11-12 Mbps upload. But I had started noticing slow down as I added 16 security cameras and most of my devices (whether TV or Mobile or PC) connected to internet. I upgraded to GIGA BYTE add on but that increased the download to 250 Mbps but reduced the upload to 6 Mbps. That was not understandable.  Either way, Tech support from XFinity suggested that I should upgrade my Modem and I finally did. It is a drastic change when you move to DOCSIS 3.1 from DOCSIS 3.0. I do not know if this is because of that alone or the fact that it also supports DOCSIS 3.0 32 X 8 but either way, my speed issues for sure are resolved. Please note that when you devices gets activated, your firmware may also get updated and for first 30 minutes, speed may not be reliable but it should eventually stabilize.
title: I just got the the NETGEAR DOCSIS 3. 1 ...

author: John S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
review_content: I bought this modem because I am a new Xfinity (Comcast) customer and was having major coverage problems with their newest high end modem/router which I chose to rent when I moved in a month ago. I am paying for 400 mps service and according to Speedtest I was getting 285 in my office near the modem/router, 165 in the kitchen at my wife's desk PC and zero in the master bedroom which is at the opposite side of the house. I also could not keep my Orbitz wi-fi sprinlkler control, which is mounted outside on an exterior wall, connected to the network. Lack of adequate signal strength appeared to be the problem. According to the Xfinity website, this Netgear Nighthawk modem is compatible with the services I am receiving from them. I bought this router on Amazon and coupled it with Netgear's Orbi router (with one satellite). Installation was very easy especially registering the modem with Comcast/Xfinity which was all done online without the need for a phone call to customer service. In minutes my modem was registered and I was installing the router/satellite. Very nice service Xfinity! With the new modem & router combination I am getting 500+ mps in my office, 450 at my wife's desk, 285 in the master bedroom and 270 at the Orbitz sprinkler box which is now rock stable on my network. What a difference. I returned the rental and will see $13/month savings on my bill. That's nice but the improvement in performance was the objective and I couldn't be more pleased.
title: Outstanding modem

author: Sherman Oakes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2020
review_content: Went through install and activation.  Seemed to go OK but no data, no voice.Had to call - but our phone service is via Comcast and our cell service is via VRZN fempto cell that back hauls via Xfinity.  Real chicken & egg problem to establish voice call.Lesson: Have cell phone that works without dependency on the Xfinity link being updated.Xfinity rolled truck w/ technician.  Spent an hour on phone with back office - Although this modem was brand new their database rejected the serial number (said it had been "deleted" and could never be used again.)  Xfinity tech left shaking his head in disbelief.So although modem seems perfectly fine, I had to return it to get an exact duplicate with another serial number.  Hopefully new one will not have same issues.Lesson:  Do not follow the printed install and do things online.  Instead, call Xfinity, wend your way through their maddening telephone tree, get to a living person, and register device *BEFORE* doing anything.Fortunately the old Arris unit was still around and could be put back into service.Plan on a couple of hours, or in my case days, of "fun".Lesson: Begin on a Monday morning in order to give lots of time for possible visit from Xfinity tech.Note to Netgear: Please print *BOTH* MAC addresses on the shipping box rather than only on the bottom of the unit itself.  Also put those addresses on the web page so that they can be printed out to hand to a tech.
title: Xfinity rejected it even though it is on their approved equipment list

author: John the Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
review_content: To summarize the below rant/vent, the product has a defective chipset called Puma 6. Google it and don’t buy the CM700.I bought this around August 2018 not knowing of the issues it has. I’ve noticed a lot of packet loss and dropped connection issues since I started gaming online.  It’s not noticeable for browsing or streaming shows but anything it’s apparent for live web TV or gaming.The troubleshooting spent on the issues were the worst. Had my ISP out 3 times and changed every possible wire run in my home. A lot of time researching and trying to track the issue.I never thought a Netgear product would be the issue but I dig around google and find the CM700 has a hardware issue, specifically the Puma 6 chip... my sleuthing continues and I find there’s a class action lawsuit as of March 2017 for the defective product!I spent more money for a brand I trusted but Netgear is showing their true colors by not doing a recall of the product AND by continuing to sell it.AT LEAST SEND AN EMAIL OR A MESSAGE ON THE APP I USE TO TROUBLESHOOT IT!I’m so jaded by this slap in the face I’m getting rid of the CM700 and never buying another Netgear product. I have several of their products at home and the office for networking and misc. stuff. So, much like I won’t recommend this product or company to anyone asking my advice, I wouldn’t recommend  this to anyone reading this review...
title: Product has defective Puma 6 chip. Research before buying.

author: James M Shepherd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2019
review_content: Cant change it's IP, at all.  No configuration to customize it other than link aggregate for port 1 and 2.  If you know what link aggregate is, this device is not for you.  Plugged the router/modem in, it booted to default IP 192.168.100.1, it issued dhcp IP to my laptop.  Logged into device though none, NONE, of the documentation that came with the router advertised the default IP or Username and password.  Once I plugged the cable connection into the router it connected to COX cable no problem.  Then it changed it's IP to the public IP at COX instead of keeping 192.168.100.1.  There is absolutely no menu to configure the actual device IP.  After searching the Netgear site for 20 min to find a phone number to call support (sounds crazy but true) I found all kinds of "create and account for support" and different levels of support that you can pay for.  Seriously.. just give me a GD number to call.  Finally called them, but instead of connecting to a tech, they want your phone number, email address, they want to create your account with their company.  I have no desire to have an account I just want support.  Too bad... no support for anyone who doesn't want yet another account on a random website that will undoubtedly spam my email or worse, sell the info to other sites that will spam me.  But hey.. finally found the user manual online for it, not by the serial number because that was not even recognized on their site.  Found in the manual, things they don't tell you, you cannot change the IP of the device at all.  Sure it's a router but you cannot change the IP.  Seriously though, if you do not know anything about networks, and every device in your home is DHCP and you have no concerns about security at all, this product just might be for you.  The good news is, I just processed the return through Amazon so my only loss is time spent on a 5 year cable modem that likes to drop connection randomly.  enjoy!
title: if you know anything about networks, this is not for you.

author: Jesse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2019
review_content: UPDATE 08/23/2019 - I got this modem because I wanted to upgrade my internet and just have my own modem. Well it seems that, according to the Spectrum tech, it wasn't compatible with the speed that I was getting (400/20). While I have my suspicions about that, they don't charge me for the modem anyway (at least here in LA), so I opted to go with their modem and return this one. It didn't really give me any issues but that doesn't account for its longevity. If you want peace of mind from the PUMA 6 chipset, go with something else, but in my short experience, I had no issues with it.Got it installed today, had a wee bit of trouble activating it, but was Spectrum's fault. Once it was activated, it ran as expected. I pay for 100/12. I get 118.46/11.80. About one megabit faster than my usual of 117Mbps upI heard about the PUMA 6 debacle and how much it can cause a lot of latency. My modem happens to be a hardware version 2.0. not sure if that means that it's not Puma 6, but I ran the online test (Google Puma 6 Test) and it seemed to be well within nominal ranges. So I might have lucked out and got a version that doesn't have the PUMA 6 chipset. So, you may be rolling the dice here, since others report that they indeed received a unit that does use the PUMA 6 chipset. If you want to be sure, go to the test page and check, return it if it's mostly red. Check my screenshot for reference.I'll update as time goes on.
title: Had it for about 2 weeks no issues...BUT

author: Molly Elkwood
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2019
review_content: The Netgear CM500 router is probably OK - seems to be working once we got a router.  My 1-star review is due to the way Amazon displayed search results when I searched for "modem router combo" . The 15 first search results returned 14 modem router combinations and smack in the middle of the 15 was this MODEM ONLY device.  Having read 5-6 descriptions of other modem router combos ahead of this one and having come to the conclusion that they are all pretty much the same, then when I got to this one, I saw that this one seems to be good value for the money. I didn't read the description or even the title well, and only opened the box when we were ready to install it with our new internet service in our new place.  Well, of course it didn't work because it is just a modem, and the laptop, also to our surprise, didn't have an ethernet port either  - so we had to go randomly driving around for a store which might sell modems in the new area of town as we couldn't search the internet for a store for obvious reasons.  SO ANNOYING and incredible WASTE OF OUR TIME. OK - it technically was my fault for not reading every single thing, but - honestly - why Amazon search results throw a modem among modem router combos is beyond me.
title: THIS IS A MODEM ONLY - search results tricked me!

author: Granimals70
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: I bought this because my network kept being dropped when streaming Netflix, Prime, etc. As it turns out, my router seemed to be the problem although it was practically new and I had to replace that also. I suspect it was overheating even though I had it placed correctly. But my old modem, which was a variant of this one, was nearly five years old and I needed to replace it anyway. I have the lowest tier available from Charter/Spectrum ( I routinely get about 115 Mbps upload and only 11mbps upload). and this router works just fine for that. If you go for the next tier (400mbps and above) you would have to get a higher rated router....I am glad I bought this one as I am happy with my internet service as it is now.
title: Good Spectrum Modem For Lowest Tier

author: Novels and Video Games
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
review_content: As the subject says, beware the fine print, I received a CM1000v2 instead of a CM1000. The CM1000v2 is compatible with Comcast Xfinity, but not Comcast Business, for the Murphy's Law example of annoying incompatibilities for no real reason other than causing issues for the customer.  From the varied responses I received from Comcast tech support, the v2 should be compatible with their Business service, but currently is delisted/blocked for whatever reason.  So, back to the seller it shall go, eventually.  Good luck, check your documentation, and check what you received in spite of your order. :|
title: Beware CM1000 vs CM1000v2.  I was shipped v2, this is not compatible with some ISPs.

author: T. Graves
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2020
review_content: This was purchased in an attempt to replace the modem I'd been renting from Xfinity at the rate of $14/mo for YEARS.  While I appreciate the DOCSIS 3.1 (The effects of which we won't really see until new devices come out) and the 1G+ speeds, this device doesn't have the advertised 4 Ethernet ports. It has one Ethernet port and three additional CAT jacks that are  intentionally disabled.  Yes, you read that right - they do nothing by design. Even the 5 year-old Arris modem that I'm turning back into Xfinity had 4 active Ethernet ports.Couple that with the fact that Netgear's support is truly dreadful (Slow AND technically clueless) and you have a recipe for sadness.I managed to cobble things together because, mid-COVID, we can't afford to have the whole house disconnected from the internet. As a result, I'll toss a new Linksys Velop WiFi6 router into the mix to make up for Netgear's failings. #SAD
title: False advertising on Amazon

author: TB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: Since this is a cable modem and one which Charter-Spectrum suggested I purchase in one of their last ditch attempts to deflect responsibility of very poor (non-existent) service from 10am to 8pm every day.  Since I had phone service with Spectrum I could only get a cable modem to pair up with the Spectrum modem for voice. Since that did not solve the problem after 8-months of service calls and attempts to get my internet working properly, I opted to cancel service.  That said, my NETGEAR Nighthawk cable modem was still within the return period with Amazon but since I wrote on the User Guide and could not find the generic ethernet cable, these two items were not included in the return.  I exchanged several emails with NEUTRON trying to come to terms with them in which they were not helpful at all and more intent on using this as an excuse to reduce my refund from $275 to $202.  Deducted $73 for a piece of paper and a basic ethernet cord (CAT 5E) I assume.  The equipment, charger and packaging was in perfect condition upon return.You have to be out of your mind to risk purchasing anything from this company knowing you will be ignored, disregarded, and robbed of your money...$73 for something that likely costs no more than $5 at best.  I do not recommend purchasing or dealing with this company for any reason.
title: Donate Big $$ if Returning Product

author: haroldtheb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
review_content: While it seems there are many who get the CM1150V up and running using the Comcast self activation link, I was not so lucky.  Calls to Comcast's tier 1 support always start with restarting the modem.  Then you wait.  Then they call back.  Finally, you talk to someone who assures you they will get the modem working.  The first agent handed me off to tier 2 support and disconnected me.  So, I started over with the restart modem, wait, call back process.  The second agent was able to provision the Internet connection, but not the phone.  Okay, half way there, so I was handed off again to tier 2 support.  I was assured that the phone could be activated by an agent who was clearly in a foreign call center.  The lag was maddening and even though the agent was hard to understand, he seemed to be saying all the right things.  Two modem restarts later -- no phone.  He schedules a technician visit to my house for the next day.  Well, the appointed hour comes and I received a call that the technician was running behind and could be there by 9:00 PM that evening.  So I rescheduled for two days later, which was the earliest the could send someone.
