Took a quick 7 minute phone call with Xfinity to set up my Motorola MG7540.The issue with the Netgear modem was that I actually DID get internet by hardwiring into it on my computer, but ONLY on my computer (wouldn't work hardwiring into my Apple TV, Apple Airport Express, or Xbox One). Neither Xfinity nor Netgear could figure out why. Dr. Google didn't know either despite scouring numerous forums attempting to find someone with my similar issue.Buyer, beware, and heed the 1-star reviews.EDIT:To Netgear’s credit, I may have gotten a lemon modem, which I understand happens. But if that was the case, Netgear should have just sent me a new modem after spending 2+ hours on the phone. Oh well.
title: Only worked with ONE device (tried on 4)

author: Alexandre Dias
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020
review_content: Didn't work when we set up. Had to call technical support. Worked for only 1 year. Our modem still works but Cox internet provider just tried to sell their modem and said ours not working.Updated it wasn't the modem but Cox connection. They blamed for the modem not working since I called them for 3 days. I brought this modem to another address and it was working. Cox technical support they just don't know what they doing. I almost have to buy another modem and trash this. After I told Cox my modem working fine they said ya your modem healthy but blah blah. They don't even know the problem come from the wire or the box outside don't connect to our modem.
title: 2 times had to call technical support

author: KARL Y.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2020
review_content: I am really excited about the Netgear CM1150V, and immediately observed a boost in network responsiveness/performance.  Nevertheless, I am giving the Netgear CM1150V a 3 because it required several hours of troubleshooting and a Support call in order to get the modem up and running (-1), and because the Ethernet ports are not available (-1).In hopes that someone from Netgear will read this post, and to certainly save you hour(s) of troubleshooting headache, I’ll go into detail on my issue.  Because if you move past the setup, this is a great modem.The resolution to my problem was to have the router(s) spoof their MAC address.tldr;About me:  Professionally, I was a network administrator, so I’m familiar with routers and their concepts.  This was not a plug-and-play installation, and thus the reason I’m rating the CM1150V so harshly.  That said, the Xfinity rep said that the CM1150V is a fantastic modem, and that Comcast partnered with Netgear to build this modem.  My initial testing is that it is lightning fast, and I thus far have no regrets with my purchase.About my network:  I had an Arris modem (rental from Xfinity).  I read about DOCSIS 3.1 and wanted to upgrade the modem because our family usage of the Internet (with three teenagers) has shot up dramatically with Covid-19.  After some analysis, I knew that we were experiencing network contention, and I needed to upgrade my modem and router.Old NetworkArris modem -> Netgear R6300v2New NetworkCM1150V -> Netgear AX8 -> Netgear R6300v2In my new design the AX8 is the primary router, and I ran ethernet and plugged the R6300v2 into an area near the bedrooms.  So it is operating as a satellite hub.I chose to purchase Netgear products exclusively because I’ve been pleased with the R6300v2 and thought that it would be an easier setup/installation.After installing and getting the CM1150V set up, I plugged a PC into the ethernet port, and was able to load several websites, so I knew the CM1150V was functional.  However, both routers had issues connecting to the Internet.  I tried several things, including a factory reset to no avail, so I reached out to Netgear Support.It turned out that both the AX8 and the R6300v2 required enabling MAC spoofing (use the MAC address of the router) in order communicate with the Modem.  Since my R6300v2 didn’t require that with the Arris, I really think they should fix this, or make it more straightforward during the setup.If you follow these steps, you can enable the MAC spoofing and be all set:1. On the AX8, click on the “Advanced” tab2. Click on “Setup” in the Left Hand Nav3. Click on “Internet Setup”4. Scroll to the bottom of Internet Setup and look for “Router MAC Address”5. Change setting to “Use this MAC Address” (after clicking the Router MAC Address will automatically populate).6. Click Apply7. Reboot the modem (wait until modem has completely booted up) and then reboot the router.I had to take these steps for both the R6300v2 and the AX8.  In both cases after I specified the router MAC address I was able to connect to the modem.Since neither of the routers had an issue with my previous modem, I consider this an issue with the CM1150V and not the router.I haven’t had the CM1150v long enough to encounter any other issues.  And as I stated earlier in this post, I have no regrets in making this purchase.
title: Great modem; challenges installing with AX8 and R6300v2

author: Christopher M. Porro
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2019
review_content: do not assume the install tech will set this up for you. also don't assume comcasts connect service via text will help you. you need to call, talk to a person, tell them you need to register a 3rd party modem. give them your MAC number, serial, and model of new modem. wait for them to register it.i had a 3 hour installation (new cable to house) where i was told that he couldn't get cm500 to sync with comcast and that the modem might be defective. so i returned it for another cm500. this time i did set up via text. where again they could not get sync. i was about to return this cm500 as well. but before that i called netgears support. they told me i had to explicitly call and ask to register a new modem. now it works fine. you would think will all the 3rd party modems listed on comcast's site they would ask during set up "is this a 3rd party modem". they didn't with me. huge waste of time.  what they did do was give me one of their modems and tell me i could get a refund on the first months rent if i returned it within 30 days. the modem they give me is listed as a "bad" one. puma 6 chip set. this is the second "bad" modem they've given me.
title: Critical to know. No help from comcast.

author: Ryan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2019
review_content: This modem works great has been an awesome addition to our wifi system. The modem works as advertised. The problem with this modem is that there are only a few vents on the bottom. The modem gets extremely hot and shuts down. I had to buy fans to use with it so that it can cool down a little bit in the summer. If there were some holes in the sides with some mesh, to prevent dust from getting into the components, it would be much better.The overheating thing is not a huge deal to me because I can fix that. The real problem with buying anything from Netgear is customer support. Their customer support is absolute garbage! I hope that if you purchase a Netgear product that you will not need to call customer support. They do not know anything about their products. I can find more on Reddit than from Netgear. That being said, if you need help, search the internet before you call them. The internet knows more than Netgear does!
title: Great modem, but gets really hot

author: Josh Foulks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2020
review_content: I use Spectrum's as my ISP and work from home. The supplied equipment that they give out doesn't even handle the speeds that they send through the lines, causing everything to work harder and burn out. I went thru 3 modems in 5 weeks, I was already using the Netgear Orbi Mesh Wifi System, and I love it, so I thought I would give this modem a shot, and my expectations were semi hight but semi-low due to the experiences I have currently had with Spectrum. Well just wanted to say that this modem was exactly what the doctor ordered. And for the first time, I'm receiving the 400mbps speeds that I pay for and my signal dropping while working remotely from home has finally come to an end, I stay connected and don't have any issues what so ever. If you have SPectrum Internet, this modem is compatible with their service and definitely worth the money for sure!!!!
title: Best Modem for Spectrum

author: Mama Bear Bethay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
review_content: Not sure why it had me rate WiFi signal - this is a cable modem. I have Cox and 150mbps service but was wanting to upgrade to the new gigablast. I ordered this because it is docsis 3.1.I have only one complaint - why have 4 Ethernet ports when you can only have one thing at a time plugged in or the internet stops for all 4 ports? Pretty pointless and a google search revealed it is a very common annoyance. I wanted to hardwire my computers in the same room as the modem, then set up the google mesh WiFi which only has one Ethernet port.. so this means you have to buy an additional gigabit Ethernet switch. Would’ve been nice to have all four ports work at once.
title: Great modem but Ethernet ports are useless.

author: Mike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
review_content: before you purchase this be comfortable setting up your own device.  After many frustrating attempts at setting this up with the instructions and calling our ISP, they sent a Tech out to 'do the deed" in person.  Once here, he explained that these units are great once programmed correctly but Comcast does not "like them" and a technician must use a manufacturer's code to program them properly.  Thus, not sure I'd do Netgear again, but once up, it's working well .
title: Know your stuff

author: Midwest Maddy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: Sadly this product started off well but in the long run it had many internet connection issues it kept giving me an unstable connection to my classroom sessions in a different country. I did not think the modem was the issue but after replacing my router and having my ISP check my connection and equipment. They found inconsistencies in the modem. I replaced it with a different one I had no connection issues whatsoever. The customer service provided by Netgear is unpleasant and no one reached out to me until I requested a refund and even with that they were rude. They stated that the firewall in their device was doing that because I needed a VPN.  It was a very dreadful experience. Buyers beware if I had not purchased the Amazon warranty I would never see my refund. I'm glad the nightmare is over!!!
title: Terrible Connection Issues/

author: Bill Bevins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2020
review_content: This is worth every penny. When I was forced to work from home due to COVID-19 I had to ramp up my Internet bandwidth so I purchased the CM1000 cable modem. I could have saved a few bucks with other brands but I had zero margin for error so I invested in the more expensive model. Boy am I glad I did. As other people constantly complain about their cheaper models letting them down, the CM1000 hums along with all lights lit!
title: Solid Equipment;Great Investment

author: PunkInParkZoo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2019
review_content: This modem does NOT WORK WITH XFINITY/Comcast - it pauses every few minutes and is irritating as hell.  If you have Xfinity or Comcast as a provider do NOT buy this modem!  Even after you call in to Xfinity customer support to update the serial number of the modem you are using.  Pauses way too often.
title: Does NOT work with Xfinity/Comcast

author: DL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
review_content: I recently upgraded from the CM500 to the CM1200 to meet the Docsis 3.1 requirement of our new provider, Wave Broadband. Out of all the Netgear products I’ve owned over the years, the CM1200 was the easiest, most convenient piece of equipment to set up. Wave had no issues initializing it in their system and it has been working flawlessly since installation. Docsis 3.1 significantly improved the quality of service and internet speed as well, so this upgrade was a total success! I intentionally did not rate tech support because everything went smoothly and technical assistance from Netgear wasn’t needed.
title: Great Experience Upgrading to the CM1200!

author: Dr JS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2019
review_content: Pre-ordered this modem to replace WIFI gateway from Xfinity.  I already own Orbi WIFI so this gateway works great for me.  While in theory it can bind two 1 gig port to create a higher throughput, very few consumer level WIFI router supports that binding, and my Orbi doesn't support it.  The installation is easy and fast.  I provided the number off the bottom of the modem and within 5 minutes I was up and running. I only subscribe to performance tier (60 mbit service) and this modem pulls in at ~75 mbit/sec.  I can see all 31/32 downlink channel enabled and 3 uplink channel enabled.Was a little surprised with the minimalist interface though. I thought it was have came with more options. Since my Orbi is the one assigning security/port forwarding etc, it was fine for me.  I am guessing if you are a power user and uses simple WIFI router with limited options (such as Google), you may find software option limiting.Overall, it works well. A bit pricey.
title: Minimalist design, fast speed, runs cool

author: Bull 2045
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2020
review_content: Was really excited about this router.  Had to have tech support do some magic to get it to work.  Once it was working it works well.  However, every couple days the 5Ghz band slows to like 20Mbs.  It usually runs around 300Mbps.  Ive been on the phone with tech support at least 5 times trying everything from  changing the channel back and forth from 153 to 161 to full router resets to changing the fragmentation length and CTS/RTS Threshold.  Now finally they give me an RMA for new unit and its going to cost me $16.90 to get a unit here then mail my old one back.  ITS STILL UNDER WARRANTY!  WTH.  This company is a crapshoot and clearly sucks every penny they can from their customers.  And just for grins I asked them if the warranty for the product resets and they said NO.  It will be from when I bought my first BROKE unit.  Dont buy this.
title: Great when it works

author: LetsTalkNerd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: As a 20 something year old, I am all about saving some money, even if there's a decent upfront cost to saving money. I've had Spectrum cable for the past 5 years and have always used my own modem to save myself from the monthly modem rental charge. Two years ago my area had a huge speed increase in our internet offerings which resulted in the need for a newer Cable Modem that was capable of handling faster speeds.NOT ALL CABLE MODEMS ARE CAPABLE OF THE TOP TIER HIGH SPEED INTERNETMy package was the 300x20 which led to me needing a new modem which is when I bought the Netgear CM700. Got it delivered, called Spectrum and gave them the MAC address of the modem. Boom. Up and running at my 300x20 speeds in 30 minutes.You don't do much with Cable Modems once they are installed but this one has worked great for almost 2 years now with absolutely no issues. It has a great design to look modern and has a good base to hold it up.Highly recommend if you are looking to not pay your ISP their monthly charge for a cable modem rental or if your current modem isn't giving you your desired speeds!
title: Easy Setup - Faster Speeds - No Monthly Charge

author: BM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
review_content: I had researched and read about the puma chip issue; but I thought it would be fine since I didn't game often. However, the same issues with latency and dropped connections persist even if using low intensity applications like internet browsing.From almost the beginning, this modem has had issues with internet cutting out. I know it's not the router because WiFi signal was still strong and the router was accessible easily. I'm going to buy the C600 that doesn't have the puma chip to see if it's better, but I would highly recommend everyone to stay away from the C700 and all its hardware issues.
title: Puma chip still an issue even when browsing

author: Ross V at Consynia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: We recently switched to higher-speed Internet service and bought this compatible Nighthawk unit from Amazon. One day in, it's delivering speeds in the range of 920 to 942 Mbps with Xfinity. Voice quality is good.We got great service out of a previous self-purchased Netgear modem: it was the 385 Mbps unit, but dependably reached 500 Mbps with our previous plan. Looking at the signal strength readings, they seemed to be good enough for the faster Nighthawk model.One thing to consider: our house had been pre-wired with a fancy junction box containing a multi-port splitter (1 in, 8 out). During our original setup and connection, the Xfinity tech checked the output signals and said they were too weak for dependable performance with TV or Internet. Because we run just two TVs and the modem, he reconnected everything using a one-in/three-out splitter. All has been well, and we're hoping this remains true with the gigabit Nighthawk. If that changes, I'll post an update.One more note: Netgear included a good set of start-up instructions in the box. Unfortunately, using the xfinity.com/activate website is a no-go on the system in our area. Instead, your options are either installing the Xfinity app on your smartphone or calling the toll-free number. Tip: the app is 46 MB so do the download via Wi-Fi BEFORE you disconnect your old modem. Calling the toll-free number, waiting on hold, providing the needed info to another human, and chatting with them while they activate the modem takes less time than downloading the app via Verizon...
title: Getting Great Performance with Xfinity

author: Wendy Ritch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_content: The CM1200, a modem only, is compatible with Optimum.  Follow the instructions, wait for the modem to register on the Optimum site (it can take a while - 5 minutes for mine; be patient) and you’re good to go.  Speedtest had me at about 940Mbps wired.  Then I installed the Deco Wifi 6 routers, 3-pack, and I have a strong, secure signal everywhere.  The only explanation that I can offer for why so many folks here claim that it isn’t compatible with Optimum is that maybe the speed they pay for is far less than the speed this device is capable of.  My plan is 1Gbps so there’s almost no loss.  Some users have reported device failure after a short time so I’ll do a follow-up review if mine fails early.  Fingers crossed that doesn’t happen!  :)
title: Works with Optimum!

author: Darren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: This seller is running a scam and if the modem is defective and you return the modem you will not have the original card credited but instead they will credit your Amazon account with a gift card!!!  My family deperately needs the money they esentially stole from me, back!  Amazon claims there's nothing they can do and I'm sure this seller will just continue ripping people off!  I needed a new modem because the really old one quit so I had to shell out the little money we have right now for a new modem and it ends up being defective.  So I returned it and then the games began, this is a horrible ploy and given the times right now it's even worse.  I can't stress enough that this seller should be avoided plus the equipment didn't work any way (the modem got extremely hot).  Please avoid!
title: DO NOT PURCHASE!!!!!!

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2019
review_content: Plugged right in and connected to my router no problem. Works great with RCN, I pay for 500mbps down and they’ve been giving me 700mbps down consistently through this router. Very easy to install, my only beef it it’s easy to tip over which can get annoying. But for what it is it’s great. Been using it three months now with no issues.
title: Good modem

author: xmei
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: Bought this modem almost a year ago. Thought it was working well until recently when everyone is required to work at home. The download speed is ok, but the upload speed is terrible, always around 0.5Mbps, making it impossible to do video meeting and other tasks. I called Xfinity and ruled out all potential problems with cable and wifi router.  I reset the modem several times, still no luck.  Then I replaced it with a much cheaper CM500 modem, problem solved. Upload speed goes up to 2Mbps or higher.  Since this one is out of warranty, I do not know what to do with it.  Disappointed about the product quality. Be sure to test its speed in time after the setup.
title: Very slow upload speed

author: Flying Dutchman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
review_content: I bought this product because I planned to upgrade my service and Netgear claimed the CM1000 was compliant with the Spectrum network. After going through the complete installation process I noted the download speed would intermittently drop to about 25% of normal, plus some webpages were not loading correctly. I called Spectrum and they said the signal was showing as consistent and strong. After telling them which modem I was using they said the CM1000 wasn't certified as compliant with the Spectrum network and pointed me to their compliant modem list. The list showed the CM1000 as "minimally compliant", which was defined as "not damaging or taking down the Spectrum network". When I called Netgear, after a very long wait, I got some Indian guy (heavy accent) on a bad connection. After repeating everything about 3 times I finally asked (x3) why the CM1000 was advertised as compatible with the Spectrum network. The response was "because many Spectrum customers have it and don't complain". I asked to speak to a second level but was told "that would be a very long wait" and then he went on to claim (several times) the CM1000 was Spectrum compatible. He would not listen to what the Spectrum Support told me, nor check the web page listing modem compatibility.The bottom line from this experience with Netgear Support is buyer beware: things are probably not as they are claimed, and tech support will not help. Fortunately Amazon is awesome and the CM1000 is already on its way back (with a full refund).FYI, one positive from this experience was talking with Spectrum I discovered that unlike Time Warner there is no charge for modems with Internet service. Since I already had a Spectrum modem for a home phone I was able to just switch everything over to that, which worked perfectly.
title: Product is *NOT* Spectrum Certified

author: Pri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
review_content: Edit: the thing died just shy of a year. I couldn't figure out how to do a warranty claim with Netgear so I tossed it in the e-recycling. It seemed like it was working fine, but my connection would drop for 2 or 3 seconds every now and then, just enough to disconnect me from whatever I was connected to, whether it was Netflix or a multiplayer game. I kept blaming my ISP, but on a whim I bought a Arris modem and my issues disappeared. I've never had a Netgear product last more than a year, you can be certain in l won't keep making that mistake.If you're going to have your cable internet service for more than a few months, you need to buy this. I'm not about to pay M#di@c*m $10/month for the honor of renting some used and obsolete junk.To set this up, literally all I did was screw in the cable (after paying M#di@c*m an "activation fee") and then plug in the power. Within a few minutes the lights were all green and I was connected.I've had this modem for 2 months now and have never had to reset it. I'm getting my paid for speeds (which is shocking considering how cable companies like to throttle speeds).
title: (not) Worth the money

author: Brandon L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2019
review_content: All I have to say is if you’re still paying like 14$ a month for the modem from Comcast then you need to unplug that Comcast modem and put it in a bag and bring it down to the nearest Comcast and give it back to them stating that you would like to have it’s price removed from your monthly bill. Make sure you bought and received this modem first or you’ll be a day or two without internet lol. Then hook this up and enjoy having a modem that operates exceptionally without a monthly charge for having it. This thing is great for performing its task. I game, stream, and have way too many devices in my house and I never have an issue. WHEN YOU FIRST CONNECT THIS you will have to call Comcast to authenticate this new device and they will try to sell you on something as usual and just keep stating that all you want is for your device to be authenticated and once you go through that process and they confirm your modem is now registered/active and ready for use you are all set. Totally worth the money for a good product that is reliable and performs well.
title: Ditch the cable modem that you’re paying for every month to have!

author: Enigma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2019
review_content: I found this to be a tad faster than Xfinity's modem/router box.At the time that I purchased the cm700, I also bought a splitter box, to link to my cell service's micro-cell, WiFi, printer  and wifi garage door controller. The cm700, only has one ethernet port, unlike the Xfinity modem it replaced. The important thing to do, if you have the need for more than one, is to follow the modem directions to a "T." I mistakenly tried to plug the modem directly into the splitter, and then out to the WiFi. Don't do that. It will NOT work like that!!!! Don't ask me why, but it won't. Found out the hard way. Call your cable company, activate your modem, plug it into your computer to verify it's active, then UNplug the connection to your computer and plug it directly into your WiFi. Once you've done that, then you can send an additional cable out of your WiFi router, (if you have another Ethernet out) into your splitter. I use a Google Mesh network for my WiFi, and luckily it had another ethernet  port, to feed out to my splitter. Your internet provider will want you MAC number to this modem, so make sure you have that handy. FYI, it’s printed on the cardboard box it comes in.At $13 a month, that Xfinity charges to rent their modem, I figure it will won’t take long for it to pay for itself.Update! Still working perfectly! And, it has already paid for itself
title: Will Pay For Itself in 6 or 7 Months

author: Tony R.L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
review_content: Took about 2 1/2 hours to finally set up, as the instructions were nowhere easy, and when I finally got it working it would ONLY connect to one old 2013 laptop with an ethernet port. Wouldn't work with my Wifi Apple base station or a Wifi extender. Tried calling Netgear support and they said there was nothing they could do as the manufacturer date was October 2018. I bought this NEW on Amazon! After this experience, I'm never buying any Netgear product ever again. What a waste of money.
title: Horrible. Stay away from Netgear

author: RRB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: I spent approximately 6 hours on the phone with both Xfinity and Netgear tech support and it never performed as advertised.  After the failure of two different Xfinity techs to set it up I was advised to contact Netgear support. Netgear tech support indicated it was not provisioned properly. Called Xfinity again and the tech said it was not fullyactivated by previous Xfinity techs. I gave up and got an Xfinity cable modem which took 50 minutes to set up. At least it works!
title: Returned

author: Mr. Timothy L. Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2020
review_content: All I wanted was a modem.  The modem installs easily and works fine.  But to register it?  You have to create an account and agree to all sorts of crap that you don't want to agree to.  And there's no way to contact them by email.  All they have is FAQs.  I won't buy anymore NETGEAR products.  All they need from me is my contact info - an email address, the serial number and date of purchase.  That's it.  For $60 I'm not agreeing to a bunch of other crap.
title: Gotta Give Up Your First Born To Register

author: Geebee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
review_content: I love my Netgear Orbi router and other Netgear products, but I'm not real impressed with this CM1200 cable modem. After 2 days of usage, it started to drop my ISP signals. Never had that happen before from a cable modem. After confirmation from Cox, it wasn't on their end, it was the cable modem. I also noticed that while handling the modem, it was extremely warm (almost hot) to the touch. I immediately unplugged the cable modem so it would cool down. After 5 hrs. I plugged it back in just to see if it would get warm again. Yep.....along with signal drops. Hate to say it, but back to Amazon it goes. I'll go with the Arris Surfboard SB8200. I've always had Arris cable modems and never had an issue.
title: Sad to say, I got a bad one....

author: Mottom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2020
review_content: All of the ports on the back don’t work. The top ethernet port works and the second  will work only if you are port doubling. I complained to netgear about this and was told that it was normal to only have one working port.... is that so; then why put all the other ones back there? I asked what I could do and was told I could purchase an external switch..... Guess what the cm1200 won’t support.....that’s right, an external switch (found that out after they convinced me to buy it). The other thing they don’t tell you is that your internet provider gets to decide what firmware package you get access to; mine doesn’t want me using port doubling, so there’s another feature I can’t use. Netgear, you sure know customer service and tech support....... you suck!
title: False advertising

author: Another Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2020
review_content: Update. 08/13/2020The CM1200 has to be reset on a daily basis and sometimes it has to be reset twice in a row. Sometimes it will work right for hours and sometimes it will only work right for minutes. Speeds constantly drop off to 30mb/s or even 10mb/s. The problem goes away once the modem has been reset. I replaced the CM1200 with an MB8600 and so far things are working normal and the way they should.We have 1g internet through Comcast so they take care of the firmware. This modem needs to be reset every 3-7 days otherwise the speeds slow to a crawl. Yes, we’ve made sure it’s the modem, not the router.We tried running the dual aggregate for a couple weeks and that lead to even more issues and bugs. It’s like this modem can’t perform the high-end tasks it was advertised to do.Just remember to call your ISP when installing the modem.
title: Do not buy, Does not work right with Xfinity/Comcast 1Gb

author: Edward Luczak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2020
review_content: I received this mid day on a Saturday and spent a half hour getting ti setup only to not be able to connect to my ISP,. I traded the online activation process several time to no avail, called my ISP tech support who tried several times but still no luck. They could at least see the device on their network but could not communicate with it. So off to Netgear Tech support in India. One hour on the phone with them trying several procedures they suggested only to come to the conclusion is was a defective product. 5 Hours wasted and back to my old modem. I went another direction to upgrade. I couldn't replace it just to go through it all over gain and wait days for shipments and returns. Seems like a good selection if it worked, but I will never know, so consider this and review other buyers experiences.
title: Defective right out of the box

author: riceinwa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2019
review_content: The CM1000 was a no brainer to set up. Once COMCAST activated, and I resolved all of my malware issues (not a result of any purchased equipment but certainly affecting all my equipment), my 250 Mbps download plan, via a NetGear AC1600 wireless router, was routinely producing 375 to 430 Mbps download speeds with 23 to 27 Mbps uploads. Rock solid performance and NetGear quality combined with NetGear's excellent customer service is what everyone using the internet wants...for their system to work so flawlessly it's almost forgotten...it's impossible to beat. (At the cable store, when I turned their modem-router back in, the techs asked what hardware I had chosen, they were all in agreement — the CM1000 is excellent!)
title: Crazy Fast!

author: Aesir
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2019
review_content: I bought this modem the moment i saw my cable provider offered a docsis 3.1 gigabit package.  i used my 3.0 modem until it arrived and was getting max speeds (for what it was rated) off of it.After the new modem arrived i experienced some issues getting anywhere near my rated speed for the package i had.  I swapped out the coax cable with a shielded one and bought all new cat 6 Ethernet cables and that did the trick, for the most part.When this modem is doing its job i have no complaints, but i have to power cycle about once a week in order for it to do it's job.  Furthermore in order to get full speed i have to unplug the modem and router.  Plug the modem in and wait until it's fully booted.  Then i have to plug in the router when its fully booted.  Also i must do this when my computer is turned off.  If i dont follow this very precise order i end up getting 30% speeds at best.The funny bit about this is that doesnt matter what sort of internet package i have; 30% is the max unless i go through  the process exactly as described.  As i recently downgraded back to a 100 mgbs package because the gig package was simply too expensive for what i was getting, and when i do speed tests i get about 30 mgbs unless i do the above mentioned song and dance.For the record the modem has done this for both my old wireless N router as well as my new Asus router.So in conclusion i dont know if i got a dud or not but i have eliminated all of the weak links in the chain and it is the only one left.  Sadly i am beyond the refund phase or i would go that route.
title: too finicky

author: Bruski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: I purchased this modem to replace an old outdated Motorola Surfboard modem that I've been using since 2012. The only issue was not with the modem, but with Spectrum. The self install website kept repeatedly crashing after a few screens, and wouldn't let me set it up. I finally called and after waiting for quite awhile and being hung up on once, they finally activated it. The modem is very stable and I'm getting even faster download speed than I had before. I think this is a good modem for a good price.
title: A Good Modem

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
review_content: After several hours of trying to get two wired devices to work using this modem (yes, there are 4 ethernet ports on the back), I finally downloaded the manual and discovered, to paraphrase, "this device is a modem, not a router.  Only one ethernet port will work at a time.  You must buy and connect a router to accommodate multiple devices."  I never expected a company like Netgear to flat out lie in their product description.  Very disappointed.
title: Very deceptive product description - Only 1 Ethernet port, not 4

author: tony
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: Hooked everything up the internet worked for 10 minutes and then all the lights shut off except the bottom one Stayed solid amber. Reset power multiple times. Tried different outlets. Turned modem off for 15 minutes and tried again. Same problem. Called and sat on hold for them to tell me in need to send it back for a refund and another won’t be available for another month.. big waste of time and will be without internet till Incan order a different model that’s available.
title: Worked for 10 minutes

author: Doc Jables
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2019
review_content: Comcast told me that they needed me to trade in my modem/router for a newer one with Docsis 3.0. I already had my own router and had disabled their internal router so I was just using theirs as a cable modem. Rather than trading in and continuing to lease their equipment at $11/mo, I bought this modem. It has been rock solid after a 19 months of operation and easily matches the maximum speed of my internet service tier (100Mbps). It was also a breeze to get registered with Comcast. I was up and running very quickly. And it paid itself off in under 6 months. Pretty much one of the biggest no-brainer purchases I've ever made.If I had to list a con, it is that this unit is so lightweight that between the stiff RG cable line and ethernet cabling, it won't stand up on its own. Its physical orientation is dominated by those cables being plugged in. It was a simple fix with double-sided tape though.
title: Reliable at 19 months and counting

author: J's Review
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
review_content: Listen here, the only reason this modem didn't get 5 stars is because of the price. I could've bought 3 Venti Mocha Latte Fraparappies for this cost, but then again if I did that, well, I wouldn't have internet. Do you want a modem that is slim compared to an elephant? This one will do. Do you have a fast internet connection and want to game or stream or any number of other things at over 300Mb/s? This puppy will do it for ya. Not gonna lie, there are cheaper modems, smaller ones too. That being said, NETGEAR will never treat you wrong and I've been brand loyal for far too long to change now. Want to know the setup process? 1. Plug in the coaxial cable 2. Plug in the Ethernet cable from the modem to the router. 3. Plug in the power cable and hit the power button. That's it.
title: Best dang modem you could ever want

author: Scott Cox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2020
review_content: First of all this is not a router this is a modem this device will pass the Public IP of your ISP out its network port, IT WILL NOT ISSUE DHCP.  This device is if you are going to use it with a Router/firewall.  Now with that being said I love this modem I plugged it in hooked up my coax cable into it and plugged the ethernet port of it into my Router WAN port and my router picked up my ISP Public info and Bam! internet that fast i did not even log into the Modem. It is passing 500Mbps down 500Mbps up just fine with no problems so far, It has been up and running for 2 weeks now with no issues or reboots.
title: Cable Modem Not a Router

author: jcmiller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
review_content: Don’t buy. Stopped working in less than 1 month with intermittent dropped internet connections. Modem became very hot. ISP came out and checked service, which was okay. Netgear support not real helpful. Modem kept on loosing internet despite multiple hard reboots. Eventually completely failed but now 5 days past deadline for return to Amazon. Amazon got netgear to help (third time). Netgear agreed to replace, but I needed to send modem in first at my cost or pay $16 to have them send new modem first. Unfortunately, I’m at my my winter residence, and netgear required shipping address and billing address to be the same, so this would not br an option. Only option was to send in modem first, expect at least two weeks without internet. Faster to buy new modem (anything but netgear) from Amazon with free overnight delivery. Now I’m out $58? Will never buy netgear again.
title: Don’t buy!!! Stopped workin in less than one month.

author: Historian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2018
review_content: Although expensive, this router does what it claims.  Keep in mind that this is a DOCSIS 3.1 modem whereas many others out there are only DOCSIS 3.0.  Buying into the higher standard now will push off obsolescence.I purchased the modem for use with Xfinity's internet service and my download speeds went from 150MBps, limited by my old modem, to 290MBps.  Thanks to other reviews, I called Comcast with the device serial number and MAC address before hooking it up.  They then stepped me through the startup process.  It took about 15-20 minutes.  My Netgear Nighthawk router required me to log into it once the new modem was on-line so you should have that username and password handy.The faster speed was immediately confirmed using Comcast's Speedtest website and accessing it with a laptop plugged into the back of the router.  I did find that the faster speed only showed up on wireless devices that could access the 5G band of the router.  Not all our devices, like older Roku boxes, have 5G capability and didn't benefit in a big way from the speed boost.  Newer iPads do pretty well as long as they are connected to the 5G band.I also noticed that I had to buy a new WIFI receiver for my desktop computer as the old one, although rated at 300MBps, didn't really get that speed and topped out around 180MBps.  I replaced it with a Netgear AC1900 receiver, which is also expensive but gave me 100% of the max speed being sent by the modem and router.  Altogether, it cost about $240 to get the new speed bump from Comcast.  Of course, you can opt to lease a new modem from Comcast instead of buying it.  In my case, the new modem pays for iteself after about two years.I do owe Comcast a note of thanks for sending an email that my old modem would not give me the higher speeds and when I called their customer service to confirm, I actually talked to someone who knew what they were doing and talked me through using 5G, checking older devices and making sure that routers and receivers were all gigbit rated.
title: Does bring faster speeds but make sure your router supports 5G!

author: Warren Ezra
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2019
review_content: Decided to replace the Xfinity rented modem with one of our own.  I read a lot of reviews and this is the one that I decided on.  It literally took 3 minutes for the Xfinity Rep. to enable the modem.  You simply unplug the Xfinity modem, remove the cable and (if you have a seperate wifi router) you unplug the ethernet cable and that is that.  You then plug in the Netgear modem, attach the Xfinity and ethernet cables and you are off to the races.  You only have to call Xfinity and give them the serial and MAC address numbers of the Netgear modem that is that.  The wifi signal is stronger and we are having absolutely no issues of any kind.  The modem is also less than half the size of the Xfinity modem, making it easier to tuck away and out of sight.  The best I can say is that it simply works.... which is what you need it to do.  And, yes, we are getting over 300 kbs in the house with little fluctuation.
title: Very Easy To Install and Enable

author: fogdrip
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2020
review_content: We got our first gateway/router about 25 years ago - many more were to follow. Installation was always a struggle! Now we got the CM1150V, Wow. The installation went exactly as it’s supposed to. We first hooked up the Nighthawk via ethernet and it worked great! The only hitch was activating the modem with Comcast. It said it would take about 10 minutes, but it was closer to 1/2 hour when I checked our email (on my phone) and found an email from Comcast saying we were activated?? So I got out of the activation program, rebooted and BAM, we were all hooked up.We later added a Netgear router (AC 1750). Again install was flawless. I’m packing up the Comcast gateway and look forward to not paying rental for that thing forever. Oh yeah, signal strength much better throughout the house. So far, very satisfied.
title: Easy Setup . . . Great Product!

author: DaveNLR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
review_content: The cable modem worked correctly.  My previous speed was 100/10 and it was 107/12 with this modem.  A bit higher than I am paying for.  I did have an issue with several T4 timeout errors (uplink), and since this modem is in an electronics closet, even though it was on an open shelf with plenty of airflow, it got quite hot.  I placed a USB fan drawing air through the modem, and cooling it, and noticed the errors dropped considerably.  Now I can go days between errors.
title: Works as advertised, but a slow speed fan helps.

author: Jim Breedon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2017
review_content: I purchased the cm 500 after 2 weeks of researching modem & router combinations. I changed ISPs & wanted to get the most bang for the buck. That meant purchasing my own modem & router.Although the cm 500 is an older model, it has more than exceeded my expectations. Set up was automatic (comcast) and instructions very easy to understanding. I have a medium tier internet connection (60Mbs) and the cm 500 hasn't skipped a beat. I have "cut the cord" so having adequate bandwidth & no internet issues was a must. I have 2 FireTV boxes with SlingTV running, 2 desktop computers, 1 laptop & 3 phones simultaneously connected to my home network. I haven't had any issues.I am very pleased with my purchase & would recommend it to friends & family.
title: Great Modem, great value

author: Mike N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2019
review_content: So no one wants to rent their modem indefinitely from the ISP.  $11 / month adds up to $132/year, so the savvy thing is to buy a solid 1000mbps unit for $169, break even after 15 months, and be saving money after that. Right? It seemed that way. This modem was simple to install, easy to use, and reasonably fast. The math made sense until the modem straight up stopped working 8 months later. The 'internet' light started blinking on and off, and no amount of power cycling or setting resetting would change that. After several conversations with my ISP, they were able to confirm that the modem itself was the issue, not the internet connection, and that since the modem wasn't one of theirs, I would have to go through Netgear for support.Netgear support is hard to reach, slow to pick up the phone, and they refused to troubleshoot the settings on the unit because it was out of the 90 day support window. The tech was ready to hang up until I mentioned that if he couldn't troubleshoot it, I wanted to replace the unit under the one year warranty. I think they're banking on customers not being aware of that warranty, because he certainly didn't mention it. Only after I mentioned replacing the unit under warranty did he actually try to see if something was wrong with the unit, and after a few minutes of guiding me through basic troubleshooting I had already done, he told me I could send it in because it might be defective.I had to pay $16 shipping on the unit to get the replacement expedited - they do have a "free" shipping option but that takes two weeks because it requires you to ship the defective unit in before they sent the replacement. But who, in 2019, would be okay with another two weeks without internet? For $16, they actually ship a new modem out to you first, and then you can send the defective unit back in the box they sent with their own shipping label.Now, in addition to being without internet for over a week, I have spent a total of $185 on this modem. Redo the math: the cable provider charges $11/month for their own rental, so I would have only saved money with this modem at 17 months. But anecdotally, the actual life span of the unit is 8 months, so hitting 17 months isn't a sure thing. You could get really unlucky and have the unit fail *after* your one year warranty is up. In 8 more months when my replacement unit once again inexplicably stops working for no good reason, I can tell you my next modem won't be purchased from Netgear. After this experience, I might just bite the bullet and rent my next modem from the ISP. At least at the ISP's stores, the $11/month rented modem can be traded in for free and on the same day.
title: Comes with a one year warranty. You're gonna need it.

author: A. Marte
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: I bought this modem hoping to save a few bucks from the monthly rental of my isp's modem about six months ago.It was working fine up until around two months ago.  The speeds started dropping drastically.  I went from getting an average of 150Mbps speeds to less than 10Mbps.  At first, I thought it was my isp, but after doing some tests I found that it was the modem.  I contacted tech support and they said that since I was still getting internet signal that the modem was working fine.  Well, I switched to another modem and my speeds jumped back to the normal high speeds that I was used to prior to setting this modem up.  I asked them to replace the modem since it's a known issue that their modems tend to fail after a short time (see the myriad of bad reviews all stating the same thing).Well, they didn't want to because again, since I'm getting internet then the modem is working.  So just be forewarned that you may be wasting your money on this device.
title: Heed the reviews.  This thing stops working properly rather quickly

author: Tim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2020
review_content: In order to keep this modem online you have to reboot it daily or sometimes more.  It will randomly stop communicating.  Even hitting it's ip address directly will get you no response.  A reboot fixes it for a time, but the time between lockups is random and will eventually make you just toss the thing.  Paying the cable company to provide a modem is cheaper than the life cycle and headaches of this thing.  I will not be using them again.
title: Locks up Daily

author: SamMo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review_content: Bought it March 2018 and died in May 2020.  Worked flawlessly for all except last two months when it started intermittent loosing synch with ComCast cable.  They came out inspected lines signal is great and they said probably modem bad.  I tried with an older Arris SB6141 and that worked flawlessly so Netgear modem was definitely faulty.  Bought an Arris SB8220 on Amazon this time.  Buying a modem every two years is still cheaper than paying $14 + tax each month to ComCast to rent theirs.
title: Dead in 2 years - but thats OK!

author: Z. Middleton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2020
review_content: Every 20 minutes there's issues with the connection. I can't revert to an old firmware or update to a new one because Netgear closed that off and leaves it to the ISP to maintain the firmware. I just have to sigh, reset, and wait 2-3 minutes for the modem to reboot. If you search on google, you'll find plenty of evidence of this happening across all ISPs. I'm out of my return window, so I have to suck it up as an expensive lesson learned. If you're going to buy this, beware, and don't order until you're ready to plug it in so you can return it when you have problems with it too.
title: Netowrk issues eery 20 minutes.

author: M. Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2019
review_content: After the modem started to lose connectivity repeatedly throughout the day, I called my cable provider. They confirmed it was the modem. I will never buy netgear again. Not because the modem did not last but instead because of their customer service. They say anything to not replace the modem. I had a total of two phone calls each one hour long before they agreed to send a replacement. But they need my old modem back first so unless you don’t want internet in your house you are almost forced to buy a second modem in the meantime. If anyone heard the things I heard on the phone with netgear customer service they would also never buy this brand.
title: Broke in a few months

author: BPPilot
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: This is great! Docsis 3.1 modem supported by Comcast. Super easy to install and configure (takes about 15 minutes). This is a MODEM not a ROUTER, There is NO WIFI. You need to have a firewall/router in addition to this. Now I just need to find a good gateway which will take LACP on the WAN interfaceUPDATE: Unable to receive support from NetGear. Device will not stay connected behind a splitter - Comcast has verified signal, at this point NetGear support won't troubleshoot without purchasing an $89 service contract despite being under warranty.
title: Fast internet, Save money, easy to install

author: Douglas McCloskey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: Purchased this based on the reviews, guess those weren't entirely accurate. This modem lasted 36 days. Also cost me a service call from my cable provider since I was sure the "new" modem wasn't the problem, boy was I wrong. Had to hook up my old modem (purchased in 2015) while I try and contact NetGear. Modem should last longer than 36 days. Buyer beware.
title: Don't Buy

author: Jacob Harvey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
review_content: The first device sent from Amazon Warehouse was DOA. Sort of. Someone had used it and not disconnected it from their account, so the Xfinity tech couldn't do anything with it. The second CM1150V worked right out of the box. I didn't have to talk to anyone over the phone or do anything more complicated than following the short quick start guide. And even that was slightly overkill (they have you take down a bunch of info I never needed to use). Since the tech set up a rental device (we've since returned) and service was activated, I entered a couple of form fields, the Netgear provisioned itself and after rebooting a couple of times, came online and we had Internet.So far it's working well. We have a free upgrade of gigabit for the next year, and when directly connected to my network, speed tests exhibit that. And saving a bit more with Amazon Warehouse means we offset the fourteen dollars a month for a rental AND it pays for itself in about a year.
title: All the power needed to keep up with Comcast gigabit.

author: David Moorhead
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2019
review_content: I bought this modem after a few weeks of terrible experiences with the "approved" SB6190 on Spectrum.  After calling to confirm that they would, in fact, provision this unauthorized modem on their network I bought it and set it up.  Speed was increased, and the random lags and disconnections I experienced with the Puma 6 chipset in the SB6190 are gone.  On day 1, it's a noticeable improvement.  I will update this review if anything changes down the road.*4 months later I am happy to report that this modem is rock solid.  No lags, no dropouts, consistent speed.  Highly recommended.
title: As usual for Amazon, a bunch of reviews for different models here.  I am reviewing the CM1000.

author: Joshua A. Nehlig
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2020
review_content: Was excited to upgrade after increasing my internet to spectrum’s ultimate at 400 mbps. After installing the modem, which was straight forward, I contacted spectrum and registered the modem. Modem speed was initially confirmed at about 400. Soon after though, I noticed my wireless mesh speeds were no where near 400. I got extremely inconsistent results via internet speed checks and the most I would see wirelessly was about 160. Went through a lot of trouble shooting with spectrum and they finally came out and hooked up there modem. Suddenly all the problems and inconsistencies stopped and my wireless mesh was running at 395mbps are the main unit and at about 200 to 250 at the satellite units consistently.
title: Problematic and inconsistent speeds and dropped signals

author: Laurence Cable
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2019
review_content: I have ordered this modem 3 times now, chickening out twice before after reading the negative reviews here.Anyway this time I took the plunge and actually unwrapped the box and replaced my 2008 (yes!) DOCSIS 2.0 Linksys/CISCO DM1000 which has worked *flawlessly* and almost uninterrupted since it was 1st installed!The install was pretty flawless, Xfinity activation could not initially detect the new modem attached but given sometime it finally did, and everything thereafter appears (so far) to be working flawlesslySo my Xfinity speed test went from ~250mbps to ~325mbps replacing my faithful 2008 DOCSIS 2.0 with the new DOCSIS 3.0 modemI can only *hope* that this netgear works 1/s as well as the Linksys DM1000 it replaces ... I guess I will hang ontothe Linksys "just in case..."YMMV
title: I finally took the plunge ... so far so good

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2019
review_content: Do not buy this product unless you hate yourself.I bought this product only because Comcast forces you to have it as your ONLY option under a Gigabit speed triple play package. I didn't even want the triple play however, Comcast wont let you have Gigabit speed unless you get the triple play package. That is another separate rant, and not about this rage inducing product.This product was SO TERRIBLE that I never want to buy another Netgear product!  Here are a list of things wrong with this product.1. This product is incapable of maintaining gigabit speeds. - my best speed test result was 500Mb, my worst was 15Mb  The average was probably 200Mb.  The results of each speed test is WILDLY inconsistent and the speeds during the test itself are WILDLY all over the place.2. The firmware for this modem can ONLY be controlled by your ISP  - forums posts said older firmware worked better, but TOO BAD you cant change it.3. Plugging anything into the modem WILL require you to reboot the modem - You will not get an IP for any device you plug in until you power cycle the modem.  Just imagine the fun I had with that while troubleshooting this piece of crap.4. Netgear's support for this product is terrible  -  take a look at the forums for this product. There are LOTS of complaints, and from the timestamps on the posts, things will not be getting better anytime soon.5. This modem is expensive for a non-functional piece of crap -  at the time I bought it $240..... What a Joke!!!6. This modem will send your blood pressure through the roof.  -  I troubleshot this piece of junk for the better part of a RAGE filled week before giving up on it. This product will make you unhealthily angry.7. This modem will make you lose money -  The HORRIBLE experience we had with this modem made my GF say that she doesn't want any Netgear product in our house.  I honestly agree with her, Now I have to buy a new router because I have a R7000P router that I cant stand being in my house.Things that are good about this product.1.I think that about sums up my review. My personal story ends with me giving up on gigabit speeds and going back to the plan I had before a painful week later.If you are masochistic give this modem and Comcast a try.
title: Do not buy this product unless you hate yourself.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: I bought this when I knew I was going to have my provider (Mediacom) for a long enough period of time to offset the cost.This modem has been trouble free the entire time I've had it. It's rarely been rebooted (and the times that it has have been related to other problems, it was just part of my troubleshooting), and provides speeds as fast at the day I bought it.Why pay $10/month for whatever modem your ISP happens to throw at you, when in just under 2 years you've paid off the difference, and never have to worry about a modem fee again!
title: 2.5 Years Troublefree!

author: R.S.G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: After calling my ISP and have them add this to their system it works good.  One thing I did notice is  a little lagging in download speed.When I had my rental modem, it always kept at 300+ in speed.  I did notice that I lost some of the speed and holds at about 150+ through 250+.  I expected a little loss as far as speed.  Tested with:  Speedtest.netOverall it does work fairly well for my needs.  I probably will suggest the Net gear cm1000 model though just because their rating of speed is higher..  I am happy so far with performance and hope that as upgrades come available I will regain some of the speed loss.
title: Netgear CM700 works good.

author: Ravi Venkatarama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: Works right out of the box. Had to call Xfinity to give them the MAC address of the Modem. Has three Ethernet ports for wired devices. One went to the WiFi Router leaving two for hardwiring devices.Well balanced and sturdy build.I do recommend for normal households.
title: Super fast and east setup

author: L. T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2019
review_content: As much as I hated to do it, I had to let go of a perfectly fine modem (Linksys CM3024-docsis 3.0) unit for this which is docsis 3.1. If you can get the 1 Gig service, you need to upgrade to this, or let them rent you theirs. I have not changed my wiring to RG6 with only one line in, but I am hoping for more consistent numbers once i clean up my house wiring. So if you are trying for 1 gig service, this will have to be the road for you. I do notice the speed increase, because everything just pops up on my screens. Other devices like my camera system do slow it down quite a bit, and of course the amount of other traffic on system, but this is about your only way I can see to get close to the advertised speed without renting from them.UPDATE: After using a Netgear router with this modem, the router turns out to be bad. And it was a nice one that I updated. I really don't like Netgears' approach of asking for money for phone support after a few months, so I have gone to TP-Link for a router, but they don't sell a docisis 3.1 modem yet.
title: Need this to get Comcast/Xfinity Gigabyte service

author: Andrew G. Drott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: Two stars because when it’s actually working, the speeds are great.  I’ve had to restart this everyday, and now I’m having to restart multiple times a day.  I bought this because it’s the only Comcast modem with telephone jacks that gives the speed I’m looking for, but if it doesn’t work what good is it?  Stay away.  I’ll be going back to my old arris modem that’s slower, but always works.Update:  I now have a $250 paperweight.  Stopped working a little over a week past the return window.  Put my old arris modem back in and I now have consistent internet.  I'll never buy another netgear product again.  And Comcast needs to take this modem off their list of approved devices.
title: Needs rebooting multiple times a day, stay away.

author: Alex
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
review_content: Activation took a while since you have to hook up directly to the pc no router and turn off pc then turn on over then turn on modem. That’s the only way Comcast was able to activate via the xfinity app.  I bought it for gig speed but I’m barely getting 700mb . I’m reading that speeds vary but then it’s all just a scam they advertised 1gig speed but you barely get past half. We need google fiber here in Chicago!
title: Works but don’t expect much from xfinity internet speeds

author: Tech Horizon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: I purchased this modem to replace my older Motorola surfboard, this netgear arrived in very good shape, especially for a refurbished product. Some minor surface scratches, but this will not affect performance, and was expected when purchased.This modem is capable of speeds of up to 300mbps depending on your ISP, my previous Motorola was topped out at 100mbps, so this is a decent upgrade. After switching the cables between the two modems, then simply plugging my laptop in directly to this modem, I was able to simply activate this new modem with Xfinity (Comcast) the overall process took less than 15 minutes. Everything has been running smooth since, and this is by far the best purchase I made. If you're leasing a cable modem from your ISP, buy this and save your money!
title: A very good performing modem

author: Richard C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2020
review_content: As others have stated, this product is pure crap. Works for a month and just started capping out, restarting on its own, lights keep blinking and won't connect. I tried resetting to no avail. For a $200 modem, I expected better. This is the second time Netgear has failed me, once with the X6 R8000 and now this. Unreliable manufacturer and products, I gave Netgear one too many chances. Never again.
title: Stay away from this modem or anything Netgear

author: Leo P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2020
review_content: Best set-up instructions ever. They even tell you exactly what your internet provider will need in a short list.  Xfinity lady was so happy too.  Went fast and easy. Instructions tell you what to expect, like pics of which lights are supposed to blink and how long it takes to set itself.  I went with separate modem and router as the router seems to be what fails most. Working well.  Fast.
title: Works great with terrific instructions by Netgear

author: Jesse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2019
review_content: So I was dumping my older DOCSIS 3 Modem/router for a newer DOCSIS 3.1 Modem and got this one after a lot of looking. It is supported by Comcast so set up was a breeze without having to call Comcast CS and be on hold for 30 minutes. The Modem basically registered itself after I supplied my Comcast log in information. After rebooting a speed test showed 178Mbps down and 6Mbts up, which is much faster than with the older Comcast router combo, also lowered by bill by $13 a month by not renting their equipment. Onlt had it connected for a few days so time will tell how reliable it will be, but I have had really good experiences with NetGear in the past..
title: Easy setup, no need to call CS

author: Shawn Guffey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: I wasn't actually renting a box, I'm a tech and have always had my own modem. However, we had a lot of internet issues that I won't bog you down with tech speak while I will include one for the techs. Our previous modem couldn't handle very many sockets open at once and was bottlenecking data, big time. With 2 gamers living in the apartment, we needed an upgrade but didn't want to spend much. We found this model compatible with our ISP and got it. We have not regretted it for a second. It does what it's supposed to and it does it well. Easy set up and forget it. Though you should reboot it now and then to bring your ping time down.
title: No more renting a box from the cable company, yay!

author: nhnonna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2019
review_content: Love the design of this super fast cable modem.  I did my homework/research and felt that this was the best equipment choice for my cable internet connection.  I also thought about the future and any updates/upgrades my internet ISP broadband company might perform.  The Netgear CM1000 was that solution.  It was absolutely the easiest equipment install I have ever done.  I read the install directions prior to tackling the install on my own and was pleasantly surprised.  I ended up speaking with the Broadband company I have, giving the lady the MAC address, she put it in the system and before I could thank her, it was up and running.  I purchased brand new, as I didn't want any possible issues to come up with a used one.  It was well worth the money to me and I feel this will last me a long time.  Synopsis:  Do the research, read the installation directions and go step-by-step and you will be fine.  I am now debating if I should buy a new router, as the one I have is a few years old now.  There's always somethin' eh?
title: Netgear CM1000 install

author: Robert C
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2019
review_content: This thing is junk.  I only had it online for 4 months. Then the troubles started with upstream issues, down stream issues, and telephony issues.  I spent multiple hours on the phone with Comcast before I finally got tech support, and did a 3 way call with Netgear..  They pointed the finger at each other.  Finally I got a Comcast guy who knew what he was talking about and together we determined from WEB searches this thing has major upstream and firmware issues.  Comcast confirmed I did over 180 resets.  I own a lot of Netgear stuff.  I am ready to chuck it all and go to another brand of equipment.  Very disappointed in Netgear, they used to be my favorite.  I used to recommend them to everyone.  Paid $249.99  NO MORE!
title: This thing is CRAP!!!  Avoid like the PLAGUE!!!

author: Mark N. Decker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: I have always trusted Netgear, but this was a miserable experience. Shortly after setting up this model, I was having to reset the modem every other day or so. Then every day. Then multiple times per day. I contacted my ISP and confirmed the problem wasn't on their end, but Netgear support wasted a ton of my time insisting it was likely the cable company's problem, and saying they wouldn't even initiate replacement procedures until I waited several days and had a cable tech out to check the lines and such. Finally I just returned the darn thing. I hooked my older modem back up, and it's working just fine.
title: Disappointed is an understatement

author: -T
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: 30 APR 2020This modem works with Comcast just make sure you have a wireless router. This modem was easy to set and took less than ten minute for me to set up. Everything that was needed for set up was included in the box. It is a much cheaper and viable option to purchase a modem rather than renting one from your internet provider. I have not had any issues with this modem and I have always been a fan of Netgear for their quick setups and customer service.
title: Why rent when you can buy!

author: Brandon A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2019
review_content: The CM1200 is a great modem for Xfinity's fiber services. I consistently get 941-946 down and 42 up via Ookla and through their Xfinity Speed Test.Overall, I do highly recommend this modem if you plan to have 1-2Gbs services and not having to lease a company modem. I do have this modem connected to an ASUS RT-AC5300 for the household wireless connectivity; although the modem itself has 3 more additional lan ports (the fourth being occupied by the router) if you desire to connect directly to the modem or have it connect to other devices.I'll update this review if anything changes in a future date, otherwise its adequate for fiber speeds.
title: It's fast and reliable! No problems with Xfinity.

author: 206area
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2019
review_content: It worked good when set up w/ orbi router & satellite but then signals dropped with either the internet or the router/satellite after adding a new computer monitor. Totally got frustrating. There would be a signal dropped whether it's the internet, wifi or my landline phone. You have to contact Orbi support( which can be hard to understand at times) and then be on the phone with Comcast! Wasted 5hrs trying to get it all connected again. Going back to original modem. Too much of a hassle! Disappointed!
title: FRUSTRATED

author: Dave B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2019
review_content: I have been renting cable modem equipment from Comcast/Xfinity for years. I received a marketing outreach from Netgear talking about their line of cable modems and purchasing versus renting. I went out to the Comcast web site to see if the Netgear modem was supported with my service (1Gig internet, 1 voice line). Comcast showed that the Netgear CM1150V was certified for use with my service. I read a number of reviews to see if provisioning the modem would be easy or a pain. Most reviewers on Amazon had positive experiences with provisioning the modem on Comcast's network.For those who use the WiFi on the Xfinity cable modem/router (they call it a gateway), the Netgear CM1150V might not be exactly what you are looking for. I was not using the WiFi on the Comcast gateway (I had the gateway in bridge mode). I have a tricky space to get strong WiFi coverage, and have been relying on Netgear's Orbi to get good WiFi around our house.To provision the Netgear cable modem, you will need a computer that has an ethernet port. Many newer ultrabooks do not have one built in, so you might need to get an external dongle style adapter. To provision the modem, it was very simple. I disconnected the existing Comcast gateway, hooked the cable the modem, and connected ethernet cable from port 1 on the modem to my Macbook. Plugged in the new cable modem, and waited probably 10 minutes for all of the lights to come on. Once the lights were settled, opened a browser on the Macbook, and went to the Xfinity page. All I needed was my Comcast user and password. The modem was then provisioned by Comcast, and it rebooted. I connected the ethernet 1 port on the cable modem to my Orbi router's internet port, and connected my phone line to the phone port. Phone service was up and running, and the internet was humming along (Speedtest showed a little over 900 Mb/second download and 40 Mb/second upload). It has been up and running for almost 2 weeks now without any issues.
title: Easy way to stop paying monthly rental fees for eqipment to your cable company

author: G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2019
review_content: I have had numerous Netgear products and was looking to a Docsis 3.1 cable modem with MTA (telephone) voip capabilities using Comcast. This modem initially provisioned after an hour with Comcast support but continued to fail over a weeks period and 4 calls with Comcast it ultimately was no longer showing as online to Comcast. Had to go with Comcast lease option for XFi gateway and modem combo, worked out of the box, and I self provisioned via XFi apt. I am loathe to lease equipment and have Netgear high end wifi router I bought over 6 months ago. This Netgear Nighthawk docsis 3.1 cable modem is an epic failure. Perhaps a faulty modem, but payback period would be 2 years or so. Very dissatisfied with this product but love my Netgear router. When working would get 476 Mbps and am getting same with leased Comcast XFi gateway/router combo which worked within 10 minutes of unboxing and hasn't required a reboot since provisioning. QA/QC your product Netgear!!
title: Did not work, kept losing provisioning and then no longer visible to Comcast Support

author: MS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
review_content: This modem was great and behaved exactly as advertised, but only for a few months. Noticed the internet dropping out multiple times last week and I contacted Netgear support as I replaced this modem with another modem and the internet connection was rock solid. In order for Netgear to honor their warranty, I needed to buy a "service plan" because their support is only for 90 days after purchase. The cost of the service plan was $139 and non refundable. The netgear support representative said that they need this plan in order to diagnose a software issue, according to him as long as the lights are on, the hardware is "perfect".Long story short, the warranty is a joke, tech support is a hard sell and the modem only worked for a few months. Another electronic device bound to the landfill.
title: Netgear Warranty is a scam - buyer beware!

author: Albert Bruckner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2019
review_content: I bought this product for xfinity cable. Had issues with the internet coming in and out. Spoke with xfinity who didn't see any issues from there end looking remotely. Netgear makes you register you device and put a ticket in before you can call customer service saw no issues but said it could be background noise, but would replace the modem if it wasnt (side note call center is south asian and hard to understand representative). I had xfinity come to the house, they didnt really see any issues but did optimize the signal a little. The xfinity guy stated that in his experience "netgear products have issues". Continued to have same issues with internet and called netgear. Said they would replace the modem but I had to pay for the shipping on the device anywhere from 15-30 dollars depending on the shipping.I stated this was rediculious and would not replace it.  I currently am buying a new product, that is not from netgear, nor will I use netgear again.
title: Doesnt work well, Customer service poor

author: Kaleigh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2019
review_content: Nice modem with DOCSIS 3.1 and Multi-Gig speeds. This is only a modem, you will need to buy a router that supports Multi-Gig internet as well. I bought this particular model for use of the multiple ethernet ports so I could hard wire my desktop for faster internet speeds. However only 1 router can be plugged in and the extra ethernet ports are useless. I had to call tech support to get the internet to work through it, but I give their tech support 5 stars! Very nice and willing to help!  Overall I recommend buying the version of this modem with a single ethernet port, its cheaper.
title: Nice modem with DOCSIS 3.1 and Multi-Gig speeds!

author: Ron G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2020
